VanEck Vectors Coal ETF is ending 2016 as one the year's winners as signs indicate that demand for coal should remain strong.But the ETF is showing signs it may need a break.The exchange traded fund has climbed about 150% from its January low — a price advance that has met little opposition. The ETF this week fell below the 50-day moving average for the first time since it broke out of a base in June. That marks a potential change in direction, but so far the drop has been mild enough that it leaves the possibility of a rebound. It would also give investors a chance to buy on a secondary buy area of support.One way to tell how an ETF is acting is by checking its main components. On that account, there are mixed signals.The fund's top holding, Teck Resources (TECK) with nearly 9% of the weighting, is in step with the ETF. It also dipped below the 50-day line this week. Teck, a Canadian mining company, is fighting to get back above the line, and success would bode well for the ETF.At the same time, two Australia-based stocks also have fallen modestly below the 50-day line this week. Aurizon Holdings is forming the right side of a base, while Whitehaven Coal slipped below support after a strong run this year.Other big holdings are not providing much direction. Some are flagging while others remain in price uptrends. Consol Energy (CNX), the only other major U.S. stock in the fund, failed a Nov. 30 breakout.The coal industry may be a pariah for clean-air advocates, but that hasn't done much to slow demand. Coal remains a major source of fuel for energy producers in many countries.China is the largest producer and consumer of coal-fired electrical power. China's coal-power generation capacity will grow as much as 19% over the next five years, even as the government tries to cut pervasive pollution in its skies, Bloomberg reported last month.Chinese companies make up 23% of VanEck Vectors Coal's portfolio, the largest of any single country.Some coal is used in steel making, and the surge in steel stocks since the U.S. election contributes to the outlook for coal.On Nov. 22, Teck Resources raised its forecast for steel making coal for the fourth quarter, citing strong spot prices. It saw the blended price for its products at $200 to $205 a ton, up from a forecast below $200. Its guidance for sales volume was unchanged at 6.5 million tons.Historically, the ETF has gone through major price run-ups and declines, including one that lasted from 2011 to January's low. Because of that steep slump, the ETF has an average annual return of -10.5% since its inception in January 2008. But 2016 has been the year to own it — it has more than doubled.The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. The universe from which the ETFs are selected includes the funds listed below.RELATED:Gold And Mining ETFs Slump After Fed Raises Rates For First Time In 2016QQQ ETF Breaks Out To Best Level Since 2000 But Has Leaked Billions

November retail sales rose 0.1% vs. the prior month, the Commerce Department said Wednesday, less than expected as the holiday shopping season got underway and consumer optimism jumped after the presidential election.Sales rose 0.2% excluding autos and 0.2% excluding autos and gas.Economists expected a 0.4% seasonally adjusted increase for retail sales, as well as a 0.4% gain excluding autos and 0.3% excluding autos and gas. October retail sales rose 0.6%, revised down from 0.8%.One issue is whether postelection sentiment would spur higher spending. The IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index shot up to a 10-year high in December. The stock market has soared to record highs since Donald Trump's presidential win on hopes for big tax cuts and regulatory relief. The stock market rally both reflect and fuels increased confidence — and bolstering portfolios and 401(k)s.However, auto sales fell 0.5%, their first decline since March.Amazon (AMZN) and other online retailers remain strong. Nonstore sales rose just 0.1% vs. October, seasonally adjusted, but were up 11.9% vs. a year earlier, far outstripping other major categories. Several reports indicated that Thanksgiving weekend sales rose sharply online, with mall traffic declining.IBD'S TAKE: After initially lagging during the Trump market rally, Apple, Amazon and other big-cap techs are shaping up for potential breakouts.Department store sales fell by 0.2%, with sporting goods chains down 1%. Electronic and appliance stores edged up just 0.1% while clothiers' sales were flat. Furniture and home furnishing chains (up 0.7%), restaurants (0.8%), grocery stores (0.4%) were solid.However, Target (TGT) gave upbeat guidance last month and later said Black Friday sales were strong. Shares of Target and many brick-and-mortar retailers rallied sharply following the election and amid relatively upbeat earnings and outlooks. Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, also has risen, despite a brief sell-off on weaker-than-expected Q3 sales. Target, Wal-Mart and many traditional retailers are seeing significant online sales growth.As for hot products, the Apple iPhone 7 likely will be a solid seller. Apple iPads and Samsung 4K TV were hot sellers on Black Friday and Cyber Monday, thanks to big discounts.Hefty discounts make it hard to tell if a retailer's holiday sales will translate into big profits or weak margins.Next week, FedEx (FDX) will report quarterly earnings, with close attention paid to the shipping giant's comments about holiday shipments. FedEx and UPS (UPS) offer a rough proxy for e-commerce sales.Also next week, Nike (NKE) and mall-based athletic shoe retailer Finish Line (FINL) should give an idea about holiday demand for athletic footwear and apparel.In stock market trading, Amazon ended the trading day down 0.7% to 768.82, still below its 50-day moving average. Apple edged higher, extending a rise above its 50-day line as it nears a buy point. Target dipped while Wal-Mart rose fractionally.RELATED:Wholesale Prices Jump 1.3%, With Inflation On The Comeback TrailFactory Production Drops for First Time in Three Months

Getting your message across to your workforce takes on an additional challenge when they are based across the country and the globe.Tips on engaging a remote workforce:Bridge the gap. Phone calls and emails have value of course, but you never really get completely around having to provide a personal touch.That's from Andrew Glincher, CEO and managing partner of Nixon Peabody, a law firm with 1,500 colleagues and 700 attorneys in 17 cities.Glincher spends some two to three weeks a month traveling to his firm's different offices. This road warrior offers a perspective: "Our inventory is people, so our assets go home every night and they have to decide that Nixon Peabody is the place they want to return to the next day. You have to give them something to come back, and I think that's in the personal touch."He says Nixon Peabody has the lowest unwanted departures in the industry at all levels — partners, associates, and staff.Be transparent. Glincher says "my style is: What you see is what you get. I'm candid, I'm blunt. Everyone knows what I'm doing, and where I am. No hidden agendas. You've got to be direct with people."He sees all employees as important, regardless of their hierarchy."I want to keep in touch with people at all levels of our firm, and want them to feel completely comfortable just saying anything to me," he says.Joyce Russell, president of Adecco Staffing USA, adds "core team members must know where you are, what you'll be focused on and how to reach you. If you do a good job communicating these things to the people who need to know them, you'll eliminate inefficiencies."Say it again. In order to communicate effectively, Glincher finds, "You have to repeat yourself. You have to say things over and over again. By the eighth time of saying it, people will finally start repeating it."Hall of Fame football coach George Allen subscribed to the same belief, called the Rule of Seven. Allen said only about 40% of your audience hears a message the first time. He wasn't worried about those 40% hearing it again, but rather the 60% who didn't.Convey empathy. Glincher tries to put himself "into the shoes of the folks that you're dealing with and talking to."Call. If your relationship is based on emails only, "then you don't have a relationship," Glincher believes."Whenever I can, I pick up the phone," he said. "If my email requires more than a half page answer, then I really should pick up the phone and say, 'let's discuss.' "Rick Wahlstedt, a restaurateur who owns nine of them in different cities, including Le Bilboquet in Atlanta, advises to have preset weekly conference calls with remote locations and their executive management teams."Have them send you a list the day before of matters to discuss so you have time to digest the questions and prepare answers and/or follow-ups," Wahlstedt said. "The call should not take more than 30 minutes each week and someone should also take the minutes so follow-through is made on matters decided on."Stay accessible. Russell says remote and on-the-go executives should go the extra mile to be available to their teams."If you plan ahead, you can stay connected in most situations," she says. "For example, book flights that offer Wi-Fi services and always have a portable cellphone charger handy."Listen. Always try to encourage feedback at every level, Glincher said, "with or without attribution. It can be anonymous."Marcelo Lu, president of BASF Canada, a subsidiary of chemical giant BASF, says it's imperative to "encourage and review feedback from employees on whether they feel connected, what they need to connect and how we can help make their lives easier." This translates into more time to spend with customers.Glincher: "We're only as good as the information we get. So I urge people if they have ideas to share, no idea is a bad idea. I really try not to make the communication one way but two ways."MORE SECRETS TO SUCCESS:How To Spend Time Well, And When To Be Stingy With ItWhy Sales Pros Need To Be Ready To Play 'Moneyball'Making Yourself And Other Accountable Is Business Critical

Herewith some unsolicited free advice for the Democratic Party. Whether it's worth more than the price I leave up to Democrats to decide.The first thing to remember is that the Democratic Party is the oldest political party in the world. It's had its ups and downs over many years. Under any fair reading of history, it has done many good things for this country and the world. It is not going away any time soon.But it is in a bad way. Its chances of recapturing the presidency in 2020 depend largely on decisions by Republicans and on events outside anyone's control.Democrats currently hold fewer House seats, governorships and state legislatures than at any time since the 1920s. And the signature policies of the outgoing Democratic president — ObamaCare and the Iranian nuclear deal — are not political assets.The first thing Democrats need to do is to end the alibi game. Yes, it's a shattering experience to lose a presidential election that, until the 9 o'clock hour on election night, you seemed sure to win.But alibis don't help you win next time. Don't blame "fake news" when your candidate had lots more money to spend delivering her message. Don't blame the FBI director when your candidate violated criminal laws and the attorney general had to disqualify herself after revelation of her secret meeting with the candidate's husband.Don't blame the "racism" of an electorate that twice elected the first black president. Don't blame the Electoral College when everyone knew beforehand that you need 270 electoral votes, not a popular vote plurality, to win.Blame instead the Clinton campaign's "ascendant America" strategy — to reassemble the 2012 Obama coalition of nonwhites and millennials, on the assumption that the attitudes of other voters, notably white non-college graduates who cast critical Obama votes in the Midwest, would remain static.Exit polls showed that Donald Trump, supposedly toxic to nonwhites, ran slightly better among them than Mitt Romney did in 2012. Their apparent regression to the mean, to voting more like the national average, undercuts the theory that nonwhites, tormented by oppression and seething with grievance, will remain overwhelmingly Democratic forever.To recover, Democrats need to take a look at the map. The relevant map in this election divides the nation between coastal America (the West Coast plus Hawaii, as well as the Northeast from Maine to Washington, D.C.) and heartland America (the South, the Midwest and the Mountain West, as well as energy states Alaska and Pennsylvania). Coastal America casts 31 lar votes and 170 electoral votes. Heartland America casts 69 lar votes and 368 electoral votes.Clinton earned all but one electoral vote (Maine's 2nd Congressional District) in coastal America. But in heartland America — where Barack Obama lost the electoral vote narrowly, 206-162, in 2012 — Clinton got only 63 electoral votes, compared with Trump's 305. Yes, Trump won the 46 electoral votes of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin by a combined popular vote margin of only (at latest count) 77,193. But the fact is he didn't need a single popular vote in coastal America to win.Democrats are even weaker in heartland down-ballot elections. In races for the House of Representatives, Republicans won more than 200 seats there, compared with only 90 for Democrats. Democrats could win half of the Republicans' 35 U.S. House seats in coastal America and still fall short of a House majority. In state legislatures, heartland Republicans outnumber Democrats by nearly a 2-1 ratio.My advice to Democrats is the advice Justice Louis Brandeis gave to young New Dealers in the 1930s. "Get out of Washington," he said. "Go home, back to the states." Leave the latte-soaked coastal cocoons. Return to your hometown or set down new roots, and run for office in the heartland — and not in university towns but in real America.That's what many young liberals did in the 1970s, shoring up Democratic congressional and legislative majorities for two decades, learning from constituents rather than instructing them, participating in local civic culture rather than lamenting it. The Democratic Party and the nation would be well-served if smart, ambitious young Democrats started packing their bags and competing where their party has been falling fatally short.

Apple (AAPL) stock isn't as sweet as it once was, Barclays concluded Thursday. The investment bank lowered its price target on Apple to 114 from 115, but kept its overweight rating on the iPhone maker.Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz also removed Apple from the firm's Top Pick list. Barclays had labeled Apple a Top Pick since it launched coverage of the company in October 2015.In a research report, Moskowitz said he sees "possible near-term tumult" for Apple."Our research indicates a recovery in global smartphone growth could be pushed out," he said. "Plus, conversations with industry participants suggest iPhone sales trends could be at risk of petering out in coming months, similar to last year's post-iPhone 6S launch fallout."Apple stock fell 1.6%, to 112.17, on the stock market today. Shares touched a 10-month high of 116.18 on Sept. 19.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 56. For better-performing stocks, check out the IBD 50 list.Barclays lowered its estimates for global smartphone unit sales and revenue this year, amid signs of weakness. It now expects unit sales to increase 2.6% vs. its prior forecast for 3.7% growth. Barclays sees smartphone industry revenue declining 2.9% this year vs. its prior view of a 0.7% decline."Despite new products from both Samsung and Apple, our research is not indicating any major improvement in smartphone units beyond initial channel fill for the respective product launches," Moskowitz said.While he has a guarded view of iPhone sales, Moskowitz raised his estimates for Apple's Mac and iPad businesses.RELATED:Apple Ups iPhone 7 Component Orders In Reassuring Sign

Major stock indexes gave back early modest gains and turned slightly lower near midday Wednesday. Apple (AAPL) added 0.6% after Taiwan-based DigiTimes reported that the company has increased orders for parts and components for its new iPhone 7.Nike (NKE) lagged in the Dow, falling nearly 3%, as investors weighed its earnings report.The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 gave up 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. Volume on the Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Tuesday's level. NYSE volume was lower.Stocks might've gotten spooked by comments from Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen in front of a congressional committee. She said the Fed is is considering changes to the annual stress tests it gives U.S. banks.Airlines outperformed, while biotechs and several retail-related groups underperformed.In the stock market today, Paychex (PAYX) slumped 4% in heavy trading, sinking further below its 50-day moving average. The stock had been battling at its 50-day line for about a week as it carved a new base. The payroll processing expert's August-ended fiscal Q1 earnings rose just 3% on a 9% lift in revenue. The EPS gain was the smallest in 16 quarters.CoStar Group (CSGP) added 0.3% as it continues to work on a flat base with a 224.89 buy point. The provider of real estate information services shows four straight quarters of 20%+ year-over-year sales growth.IBD'S TAKE: CoStar is a top-rated name in IBD's Commercial Services-Market Research industry group. See the other strong performers in the group with IBD Stock Checkup.Worthington Industries (WOR) and Cintas (CTAS) both gapped up in the IBD 50. Worthington rose 3% to 45.77 after the company reported its third straight quarter of accelerating earnings growth. It's trying to clear a flat base with an entry at 45.78. Cintas rose nearly 3%. It's getting support at its 10-week moving average again after a base breakout in late June.RELATED:That Nike Metric That Sank Shares? Stop Looking At It, Says NikePaychex 2017 Outlook Dims, Stock Drifts Away From Buy PointApple Ups iPhone 7 Component Orders In Reassuring Sign

Nike's (NKE) first-quarter results were "peppered with red flags," says one retail analyst, as many on Wall Street note that Under Armour (UA) and Adidas are chipping away at Nike's stranglehold on the American consumer.The athletic apparel giant beat earnings estimates by quite a bit when it reported late Tuesday, but much of that came from a one-off tax-rate benefit, among other things, noted Canaccord Genuity's Camilo Lyon, who rates Nike a hold with a 52 price target.And North America futures orders growth of 1% — well below consensus for 4.4% — was a "disconcerting surprise" to him and "likely a result of the competitive landscape shifting toward Adidas and (Under Armour)," he wrote.Much of Lyon's bearishness appears to come from futures orders, the Nike-created metric of products to be delivered to retailers. Outside of earnings and revenue, it is largely the metric to watch in the company's quarterly results.But the Swoosh, which pointed out a declining correlation between reported revenue and futures, likely believes Wall Street is focusing on futures to a fault: Management announced during the call that it will only release the figure during the earnings call and in SEC filings, and not with the earnings release. (Nike's continued investments in Nike.com and its direct-to-consumer business may explain some of the disconnect.)Nike shares closed down 3.8% at 53.25 in the stock market today. Under Armour shares pared earlier gains and finished up 0.5%, after hitting resistance at their 200-day average.But Canaccord wasn't the only firm to highlight Under Armour and Adidas flexing their retail muscle in the U.S. and Canada.Cowen analyst John Kernan highlighted that Adidas has grown its brand sales in North America by 31% in the first half of 2016 as it increases its market share, a contrast to Nike's futures performance in the region."We think the N. American market, in particular, is being impacted by the brand resurgence of Adidas given its increasing visibility and strong product cycle, and ongoing competition with Under Armour," he wrote, calling Adidas his top pick.IBD'S TAKE: Nike is part of IBD's Apparel-Shoes & Related Manufacturing industry group, which currently ranks a lowly 186 out of 197 tracked sectors. To figure out when a buying opportunity may present itself, IBD University has tips on "how to find and evaluate stocks."Brean Capital downgraded Nike to hold from buy, while a number of analysts trimmed their price targets on the stock. FBR cut its target to 55 from 63, Cowen took its goal to 59 from 63, and Credit Suisse went to 60 from 63.But many still have faith in Nike's long-term story. Nomura trimmed its price target to 60 from 64, but analyst Simeon Siegel reiterated a buy rating on the stock."Despite the threat from a push by competition & disappointing futures, we view NKE's scale (and) dominance as a (long-term) barrier to entry (and) maintain our Buy despite what appears a nascent share loss," he wrote Wednesday.On the call late Tuesday, Nike CFO Andy Campion said he expects North America's "reported revenue growth over the balance of the year to outpace the rate of futures growth driven by stronger sell-through to consumers."RELATED:That Nike Metric That Sank Shares? Stop Looking At It, Says NikeNike's Latest Patent Filing May Boost Billion-Dollar Flyknit LineBrand Olympics: The Medal Count For Coca-Cola, Nike, McDonald'sHear That, Nike? Adidas Ups Outlook For Fourth Time In 2016

It's official. BlackBerry (BBRY), the Canadian company that invented the smartphone and addicted legions of road warriors to the "crackberry," has stopped making its iconic handsets.Finally conceding defeat in a battle lost long ago to Apple (AAPL) and Samsung Electronics, BlackBerry is handing over production of the phones to overseas partners and turning its full attention to the more profitable and growing software business. It's the formalization of a move in the making since Chief Executive Officer John Chen took over nearly three years ago and outsourced some manufacturing to Foxconn Technology Group. Getting the money-losing smartphone business off BlackBerry's books will also make it easier for the company to consistently hit profitability."This is the completion of their exit," said Colin Gillis, an analyst at BGC Partners. "Chen is a software CEO historically. He's getting back to what he knows best: higher margins and recurring revenue."Chen should be able to execute his software strategy as long as he keeps costs in line and maintains cash on the balance sheet, Gillis said.BlackBerry said Wednesday it struck a licensing agreement with an Indonesian company to make and distribute BlackBerry-branded devices. More deals are in the works with Chinese and Indian manufacturers. It will still design smartphone applications and an extra-secure version of Alphabet Inc.'s Android operating system."We are reaching an inflection point with our strategy," Chen said in a statement announcing the shift as well as quarterly earnings. "Our financial foundation is strong, and our pivot to software is taking hold."The new strategy will improve margins and could actually increase the number of BlackBerry-branded phones sold, Chen said, as manufacturers license the name that still holds considerable sway in emerging markets like Indonesia, South Africa and Nigeria.IBD'S TAKE: The days of massive growth may be past, but megacap techs Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft and Cisco are cash kings.Although BlackBerry's latest phone, the DTEK50, was already almost completely outsourced, the move is a big symbolic step for a company that once reached a market value of $80 billion. Today, it's worth $4.3 billion.When the BlackBerry 850 was released in 1999, it married a functional keyboard with email capability and essentially ushered in the modern smartphone era. With a proprietary operating system known for its watertight security, the phones became ubiquitous and extended the workday onto commuter trains and into restaurants and homes. They were an instant hit with business executives and heads of state alike. President Barack Obama was fiercely committed to his, but finally ditched it earlier this year, reportedly for a Samsung.Then, in 2007, enter the iPhone with its touch screen interface and app store. People at first said they didn't want to give up BlackBerry's keyboard and simplicity. But the lure of apps eventually sent almost all its users to phones running Android or iOS."It was inevitable at this point; they didn't have the unit volumes to sustain the business profitably," said Matthew Kanterman, an analyst with Bloomberg Intelligence. "This is doubling down on the efforts to focus on software which is really what their strength is." BlackBerry shipped only 400,000 phones in its fiscal second quarter, half what it sold in the same period last year. Apple sold more than 40 million iPhones last quarter.BlackBerry said software and services revenue more than doubled in the quarter from a year earlier to $156 million. Still, software revenue was down from the previous quarter's $266 million, which Chen blamed on patent licensing deals that didn't carry over into the quarter.Adjusted earnings were at break-even, compared with analysts' estimates for a loss of 5 cents. Revenue in the second quarter was $325 million, falling short of analysts' projections for $390 million. For the full year, BlackBerry expects a loss of 5 cents or to hit break-even, compared with what it said was a current consensus of a 15-cent loss.RELATED:Apple Ups iPhone 7 Component Orders In Reassuring Sign Apple iPhone 7 Sales Forecast Upped On Samsung Woes, High-End Models Stocks To Watch: Are Apple, Facebook And Alphabet Still Buys?
