The economics of ObamaCare are very bad. The law is inflicting broad damage on job creation and new business formation. It ruins job incentives by making…
The 'N' in IBD's CAN SLIM investment system stands for "new": new products, new markets, new management — a company that is reformed or has a fresh strategy.
All of these factors may point to a stock that is about to upshift and go places.

On the other side of the coin are fundamental factors such as earnings, revenue, margins, debt and return on equity. These factors figure significantly into determining whether a new idea can ultimately fly. Some of the greatest ideas in history failed because the minds behind them couldn't successfully manage a company.

IBD's New America feature aims to focus squarely on these aspects of potential leaders. It works to catch them early in a turnaround, soon after they turn profitable or when a groundbreaking product is released. The section then tends to track the stock throughout its advance.

Ambarella (AMBA), a current leader on the IBD 50 list, is a good example. A March 2013 New America piece caught the supplier of video processing chips used in GoPro (GPRO) cameras, among other things, just as it was dipping back below the buy point of a seven-week cup base.

The stock shot up 10% on March 25 in heavy volume, the same week that the article was published, retaking its 13.52 buy point. It gained 21% for the week and has gained 855%. Shares turned volatile after beginning to flash climax top signals in June, but remain near new highs.

New America introduced IBD readers to Ulta Beauty (ULTA), currently an IBD 50 and Leaderboard stock, in September 2009. The story outlined the company's history, including its brush with bankruptcy in the late 1990s. The article detailed Ulta's strategy to blend a cosmetics counter with personal care offerings and a hair salon, and outlined its aim to tap into demand for "affordable indulgence" even as the U.S. economy struggled out of its recession.

The stock had cleared a three-month base early in September. It formed its next base in January, and has gained nearly 1,300% (so far). Ulta is just below highs, holding above a 159.95 flat-base entry.

Alaska Air Group (ALK) is also currently an IBD 50 stock. New America in February 2010 picked up that the stock had posted a 1,942% gain in earnings at the time when most airlines were struggling. The company had trimmed capacity to less profitable markets, directing its aircraft to fly more routes to profit centers. Alaska's focus on North American travel also helped, insulating it from the fall-off in overseas tourism.
The stock was just climbing off the bottom of a cup-with-handle base, heading for a March 1 breakout.
It is currently trading more than 700% above that early base's buy point. It is just above a 71.50 buy point in late-stage base.

These are just a sample of the vast array of winners detailed in New America write-ups. Used in combination with IBD's SmartSelect ratings and features like the weekly Industry Snapshot, they offer a powerful start to any research effort.

Obviously, not every stock covered turns out to be a winner. This is why investors need to work hard to build their trading and research skills, and to know when to properly buy a stock, and how to read the signals that say it is time to sell.The 'N' in IBD's CAN SLIM investment system stands for "new": new products, new markets, new management — a company that is reformed or has a fresh strategy.All of these factors may point to a stock that is about to upshift and go places.On the other side of the coin are fundamental factors such as earnings, revenue, margins, debt and return on equity. Sometimes, there's no simple explanation as to why a stock rose or fell during a single session. But in the case of breakouts, many times it's positive earnings surprises that provide the fuel for a big rally's fire.

An earnings surprise occurs when a company reports per-share profits outside of what was expected by the investment community. A positive surprise occurs when a firm reports earnings per share above consensus estimates from providers such as Thomson Reuters, S&P Capital IQ and FactSet Research Systems. A negative surprise happens when a firm posts bottom-line results below analysts' expectations.
Profit surprises and raised profit outlooks, plus comments from influential analysts and regulatory rulings, can have big impacts on stocks.
Game Changer

The Securities & Exchange Commission enacted Regulation FD (Fair Disclosure) in 2000 to help address the selective disclosure of these items and other information that can move a stock. Company management is now barred from revealing material information about the business or financial results to a select audience. "Quiet periods" ahead of a quarterly report are now commonplace.
Since strong earnings growth is one of the main drivers of a stock's performance. There's little reason to buy shares in a company that is not making money.
A company that beats views is telling you that business is better than expected. Results were beyond what analysts using fundamental models predicted. This good news creates big demand for shares.

A company that posts a surprising profit when it was expected to lose money can see its shares skyrocket, such as e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN) did after the close July 23. Shares shot up 17% in extended trading after the company reported a Q2 profit of 19 cents a share vs. an expected loss of 14 cents. Amazon.com finished the July 24 trading session with a 10% gain.

Sometimes, an earnings beat will move a stock a few percentage points at the open. Other times, a stock will gap sharply higher in heavy volume as institutions applaud the better-than-expected results. In most cases, IBD stresses not to buy once a stock gets to be more than 5% past a buy point.

But huge gap-ups out of bases mark an exception to the rule. While scary, it's fine to buy on a big gap-up past a base's buy point. The stock must have excellent fundamentals. And you should exit the trade if the stock falls 7% to 8% from your purchase price.

LinkedIn (LNKD), which runs a social networking website for professionals, was added to Leaderboard in late December of 2012. The stock cleared a 117.42 buy point from a cup-with-handle base Jan. 10, but didn't move much after that (1).

However, after the close Feb. 7, the company posted fourth-quarter earnings of 35 cents a share, up 192% from a year ago. It trounced views of 19 cents a share. It also marked a second straight quarter of triple-digit growth.

The stock gapped 13% higher at the open the next day and surged 21% for the session. LinkedIn bolted nearly 73% by early May before consolidating gains (2).Sometimes, there's no simple explanation as to why a stock rose or fell during a single session. But in the case of breakouts, many times it's positive earnings surprises that provide the fuel for a big rally's fire.An earnings surprise occurs when a company reports per-share profits outside of what was expected by the investment community. Baidu (BIDU) and other China tech stocks fell on Monday on the heels of data showing the country's manufacturing sector is shrinking.Baidu, China's leading search engine, is slated to report Q2 earnings after the close Monday. Analysts expect the company to continue to feel pressure on its profit margins in the wake of a weak showing in Q1.Baidu stock was down 4% in early afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 199, and is down 14% this year.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are expecting Baidu to post Q2 revenue of $2.6 billion, up 38% year over year, and EPS ex items of $1.71, down from $1.73 in Q2 2014.For Q3, Wall Street is expecting Baidu to post revenue of $3.02 billion, up 37% year over year. Analysts are expecting EPS ex-items of $1.95, up 2%.Baidu stock fell sharply in April after the company reported Q1 revenue below Wall Street expectations and gave soft Q2 guidanceas it spent heavily to advance its mobile business in the face of competition from China e-commerce leader Alibaba Group (BABA)and others.In recent months, Chinese authorities have shored up the stock market and encouraged citizens to buy shares, even as economic growth looks to be flat or slowing. China's gross domestic product rose 7% in the first half of the year, faster than most countries but down from its double-digit growth rates just a few years ago. China's GDP rose 7.4% in 2014.The latest stock plunge comes as a host of China companies traded on U.S. stock markets have received offers from top executives and others to go private. They plan to delist in the U.S. and instead to go public in China, despite a crash in the Chinese exchanges that followed big run-ups that many analysts called a bubble.Even with China's stock crash, U.S.-listed China firms likely will still find that their valuations back in China will be "five to 10 times" what they're fetching on Wall Street "even though the Chinese stock markets have been down more than 50%," wrote Rosenblatt Securities analyst Jun Zhang wrote in a research report on July 8.On Monday, the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 8.5%, its biggest single-day fall since 2007, casting doubts on stabilization moves from Chinese authorities, according to a report in Monday's Los Angeles Times.The Shanghai Composite lost 345.35 points Monday to close at 3,725.56, with about 1,800 listings falling by the daily limit of 10%. That's off more than 28% from Shanghai's peak in mid-June, but is still 76% higher than it was a year ago, the Los Angeles Times report said.The Shenzhen Composite fell 7% on Monday.Other China stocks that were down Monday afternoon include: Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), down 4%; Netease (NTES), down 7%; JD.com (JD), down 7%; and Sohu.com (SOHU), down 4%.Follow Michele Chandler on Twitter: @IBD_MChandler.

This morning U.S. futures are surging - currently up 11 points in early trading as stocks used long-term support as a springboard to move ahead.... ......This after a bit of downer yesterday...when talk of impending doom caused markets to stumble......

Yesterday morning as the sun was rising over the Atlantic - European markets were in decline reacting to the beating that Asian stocks took on Monday - all Asian markets had been under assault...... Japan -1.2%, Hang Seng -3+% and according to every news source out there - China was in freefall - plunging by 8+% even the gov't could not control their market - and we know how hard they are trying. I mean look - Monday night the gov't announced that they (the gov't) would increase the purchases of stocks to try and keep the market 'artificially elevated' (my words not theirs!- but that is what they are trying to do.) This morning - Chinese authorities announced that they are investigating whether 'share dumping' was behind Monday's disaster - Oh boy.....you know what that means....

And so U.S. stocks took it on the chin yesterday......The media was quick to blame the overnight action in China - I emphatically disagree. Most Americans are not affected by the plunge in the Chinese stock market - not at all - yet the negative tone did give traders a reason to take money off the table.....….American investors might be affected by a slowdown in the Chinese economy (temporary) - but those are two very different things…what is happening in their market is completely disconnected to what their economy may or may not be doing….. The market got way ahead of itself - thanks to central bank and regulatory policy.

In the last 12 months - The Shanghai Composite is up 140%...and since January 1st - that market is up 60% - all on what? Artificially created growth -all at a time when most analysts never believed the data coming out of China - yet bought the story......Asian investors flocked to China - Alibaba (BABA) - the massive Chinese 'Amazon' that many viewed to be a proxy for investing in China- came listed to the NYSE - China was now 'on the board'........

They 'opened' their market to retail investors - sucking in the 'average Zhang Wei' (Chinese equivalent for the Average Joe) ..... seeing it as the next 'gold rush'.....and when the music stopped - everyone tried to run for the door causing the market to implode..........And then - The Chinese gov't - in an attempt to stop the bleed - halts trading, imposes regulatory limits, threatens caning and beatings to anyone caught selling and you ask - "why is the Chinese stock market acting this way?" Listen to yourself? You know the answer.....Buyer beware .

And while all the 'he-man' talk from China about how they are prepared to buy stocks to stabilize their market many doubt whether any of this intervention can really stop the bleed.....the recent action in China has caused fear among some of the investing community about the broader health of the Chinese economy, and so we see commodities getting slammed as well......slammed so hard that you would think the end of the world was coming....that my friends is not the case...and as usual - the pendulum has probably begun to swing too far to the left........Capisce?

Ok...back home - U.S. stocks have been a bit psychotic lately - reacting with a heavy heart as we moved through the Greek tragedy and now have to deal with the 'China Syndrome'...testing the will of investors as the market backed off to test long term support at the 200 day moving average. Last Friday the broader S&P 500 gave back 1%... (and a total of 3% for the week) .......China, commodities, earnings and rate increases were all the rage…..valuations peaking out at near 18x for 2015 - leaving the market nowhere to go but down - I mean how could we justify paying up for stocks in 'this environment'? - Yet 2 weeks ago - investors and traders were climbing over each other to put money to work.

Last week - some of the Dow's biggest names disappointed - Caterpillar (CAT) (all about China - or so they want us to believe that), IBM (IBM), 3m (MMM), causing broader concern for investors - and in the 'hot' biotech space (Spider S&P Biotech ETF (XBI) +34% year to date) - Biogen (BIIB) - took it on the chin giving the bears something to scream about - (but look - Biogen does not represent the U.S. economy - not by a long shot) so it is difficult to connect trader reaction to the broader U.S. economy.....….Yet the negative tone did weigh on the markets and all sectors appeared weak -with semi's, basic materials, energy and industrials all showing the greatest signs of exhaustion. This is most evident in the Dow - which has now broken all support levels - now testing the lows of late Dec/early January - returning -2% ytd.

Earnings continue to be the focus as we have about 150 more names that will report this week - Key for today - Ford (F), United Parcel Service (UPS) and Twitter (TWTR). On the economic calendar we will get - a host of Case Shiller Home reports (yawn), Markit U.S. Services PMI - expectations of 55, consumer confidence of 100 and the Richmond Fed Survey of 7.

Tomorrow brings the FOMC rate decision....now hold onto your hats - rates are not going anywhere just yet......but any hawkish fed speak will raise the odds of a September move....(Now I still believe it will be later) Expect to hear Yellen express some concern about the Chinese 'situation' and how further instability in that market could cause an economic slowdown in the global economy. The ongoing rout in the commodity space will also cause the Fed to pause and take a breath before charging ahead.
Wednesday will bring us 2Q GDP - estimates call for a 2.5% annualized rate - a weaker report will be cause for caution - but I don't think that is what we will hear at all.

Like I said - U.S. futures are up 11 points - which will put the S&P 500 right back in resistance range (2080/2085ish) as the market continues to toy with both support and resistance in the same day.....Watch for the tone of earnings today and the speculation about what the Fed will say. The market IS expecting rates to rise this year - so that is not the issue - the issue will be more about the tone of her remarks - what does it say about future rises and the pace of those rises.....that will be the catalyst for markets.

In Europe - markets are bucking the Asian trend and all moving higher. Yes - investors are watching the ongoing drama in China - but now seem to be putting all of that on the back burner - at least for today. The focus is on earnings and U.S. fed policy..... UK GDP came in at +0.7% - meeting the expectation - so no surprise there. FTSE +0.8%, CAC 40 +1.21%, DAX +1.43%, EUROSTOXX +1.35%, SPAIN +1.06% AND ITALY +1.73%

Overnight in Asia - markets there ended the day a bit lower...China did sell off 5% before rebounding to end the day -1.6%, Japan -0.10%, Hong Kong +0.62% and ASX -0.09%. Commodities continue to be the story there as any China slowdown will negatively impact commodities.....Don't know about you, but I think that has already happened right? The Thomson Commodity index is off 13% from the May highs (and is off 37% from the June 2014 highs) as investors fled that market.....We have now broken the lows of March in what feels like capitulation.....and capitulation creates opportunity - I'm just sayin.....
I am in Houston on Wed/Thurs so next note will be Friday.
Take good care.
Kp

Wireless phone companies aim to improve spotty network coverage and add data capacity by turning to "small cell" technology — a strategy that may also enable them to tap unlicensed, Wi-Fi-type radio spectrum in the long run.
Crown Castle (CCI) is the cell tower operator most likely to benefit, as it aims to play a large role in small cell deployment by wireless firms.
Crown Castle in April made its second major small-cell-related acquisition, buying Sunesys for $1 billion in cash. In 2011, Crown Castle bought NextG for the same price.

Verizon Communications (VZ), a Crown Castle customer, is leading the charge to small cell technology as data demand surges on its 4G LTE network. Wireless firms generally use large cell towers across the U.S. to whisk calls, video and email to mobile phone users. Wireless firms also use large radio antennas installed on building rooftops, church steeples, billboards, or even farm silos and fake trees.

But small cell technology is gaining ground in urban areas. The low-power "base stations" are located in shopping malls and outdoor public spaces. They're often mounted on lamp posts or utility poles, and are roughly the size of a suitcase.
There are about 150,000 full-size cell towers, operated by tower companies Crown Castle, American Tower (AMT), SBA Communications (SBAC) and others.

The number of small cell base stations is potentially much bigger, depending on whether AT&T (T), Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) follow Verizon's lead. Sprint, amid a network upgrade, is expected to deploy small cell technology in 2016.
"We think there's an opportunity for small cells in most urban environments," Ben Moreland, Crown Castle's CEO, told IBD. "It's a vast geography.

"When we look at maps that we're working on and the locations we're building out today, you can come to the conclusion that this is going to go in virtually every major suburban and urban area. We're talking about building out block by block."
The rub for Crown Castle and its rivals is that rising use of small cells might mean wireless firms will need fewer big towers, which analysts say are highly profitable to operate.
Moreland, whose company operates 40,000 towers, disagrees.
"We can find no evidence, nor a carrier customer who is suggesting it's an either/or proposition," he said. "It's complementary and additive."
Cell towers aren't going away, but small cell technology is coming on strong, says Roger Entner, an analyst at Recon Analytics.

"Carriers are going with small cells because they need to upgrade capacity in a particular spot, like an office building," Entner said. "So instead of building a larger, more expensive tower site, they prefer to do a more topical solution."

For smartphone users, small cell deployments should mean fewer dropped calls and faster video downloads. Mobile phone users share radio signals and spectrum capacity, with service degraded as more devices are connected.
Small cell technology also could help wireless firms tap a new source of airwaves, unlicensed spectrum.
As for licenses airwaves, AT&T spent $18.2 billion in the recent AWS-3 spectrum auction, the most of any company. Verizon spent $10.4 billion.

Those additional airwaves, however, won't be enough to meet long-term demand. Verizon is interested in augmenting its licensed spectrum with new airwaves that federal regulators plan to set aside for Wi-Fi-type networks.

The Federal Communications Commission in April voted to make 150 MHz of spectrum in the 3.5 GHz frequency band available for mobile broadband and other commercial uses. The FCC also is studying whether to open up nearly 200 MHz of spectrum in the 5 GHz band.
Comcast (CMCSA) and Time Warner Cable (TWC) are among the cable TV firms interested in using 5 GHz airwaves to expand public Wi-Fi services, analysts say.
Meanwhile, Verizon is keen on using unlicensed spectrum, and it's been testing a 400-node small cell system in Boston.

Amir Rozwadowski, a Barclays analyst, says Verizon has focused on its small cell initiative for about 18 months. He says Verizon's interest in small cell systems goes beyond near-term data capacity needs and is related to the "multiyear evolution of its network."

Rozwadowski added in a research report that Verizon is already putting in the foundation for a shift to next-generation 5G mobile networks. Wireless firms globally are expected to deploy 5G networks after 2020.
To get small cell systems in place in urban areas, Verizon has been working with building owners and local regulators.

Verizon also has been in talks with suppliers of fiber-optic wiring that connects small cell systems to the Internet and long-distance phone networks, or the so-called backhaul system. The fiber hook-ups speed up mobile data performance.
Zayo Group Holdings (ZAYO), which leases fiber connections to cell tower operators, has told analysts it's interested in the burgeoning small cell market.
As for Crown Castle, its April 30 acquisition of Sunesys, a unit of Quanta Services, boosted the wireless tower company's ability to provide fiber-optic hook-ups for small cell backhaul services.

Analysts say Crown Castle made the move in part to meet Verizon's needs. Sunesys owns or has rights to nearly 10,000 miles of fiber in major metro markets. So, Crown Castle now can provide fiber services similar to the likes of Zayo. That's a new business for Crown Castle, notes Rozwadowski.
Kevin Smithen, an analyst at Macquarie Capital, likes Crown Castle's investments in small cell technology and its Sunesys acquisition.

"Small cells will be a central pillar of (4G) network architecture for Verizon and Sprint in the second half of 2015 and especially 2016 and for T-Mobile and AT&T moving forward," said Smithen, in a report. "Sunesys allows Crown Castle to jump-start its business plan by several years by shrinking build-out time and spending for metro fiber networks."

In 2014, small cell contracts accounted for 7% of Crown Castle's overall revenue, more than at American Tower and SBA Communications. As in the case of cell towers, Crown Castle expects small cell installations to be share-able among multiple wireless carriers, boosting profits.

"Crown Castle has the biggest potential for upside to consensus (estimate) forecasts if Verizon and Sprint small cells kick-in," Smithen added.Wireless phone companies aim to improve spotty network coverage and add data capacity by turning to "small cell" technology — a strategy that may also enable them to tap unlicensed, Wi-Fi-type radio spectrum in the long run.Crown Castle (CCI) is the cell tower operator most likely to benefit, as it aims to play a large role in small cell deployment by wireless firms.Crown Castle in April made its second major small-cell-related acquisition, buying Sunesys for $1 billion in cash. ObamaCare exchanges have just met a target of 2.8 million young-adult enrollees. The bad news: That target was for last year. By now, there were supposed to have been roughly 5 million paying customers between the ages of 18 and 34. Lagging young-adult enrollment is among the reasons why so many big insurers on the exchanges are seeking premium hikes…

Homebuilder shares surged in the wake of the proposed $5.2 billion merger of Standard Pacific (SPF) and Ryland Group (RYL) as speculation rises over additional consolidation in the industry.By early afternoon, the rising tide lifted the boats of Meritage Homes (MTH), whose shares were up 2.8% to 44.65 in the stock market today as volume rose 88%. MDC Holdings (MDC) stock rose 3.3% to 29.68 as volume lifted 217%. Lennar (LEN) shares were up 1% to 47.96, while KB Home (KBH) stock was up 0.5% to 14.99.The surging stocks come as homebuilder confidence hit a nine-month high, rising 5 points to 59, according to National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo data released Monday. Results greater than 50 signal that homebuilders are optimistic about sales. It was the 12th straight month of above-50 hopes.Despite the optimism, the housing sector's recovery has been sluggish since the recession ended in June 2009. Slow job and wage growth, young buyers burdened with student loans and restrictive mortgage standards have been cited for the sector's tepid recovery.Ryland CEO Larry Nicholson, who will serve as CEO and president of the yet-unnamed combined company, told the Wall Street Journal: "We expect to see slow, steady growth for the next couple of years."The Standard Pacific-Ryland deal would result in the two Southern California-based companies controlling 74,000 home sites.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter: @IBD_CMcEvoy.

Government Work: Enrollment in Covered California was flat this year, and consumers hate it. But the director still got a huge raise and a fat bonus. So much for ObamaCare rooting out health care waste.

The 1.4 million who signed up for an ObamaCare plan through Covered California, and who are paying a $13.95 fee every month for the privilege, might be interested to learn that Executive Director Peter Lee just got a 26.8% raise, plus a $65,000 bonus, which is bigger than the $53,000 bonus he received last year.

To put this in perspective, Lee's base salary of $333,120 is 49% higher than the average health insurance CEO in the country, and 69% higher than all the CEOs in California, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data.
We don't begrudge people for being well compensated for their success. But in this case, Lee is being rewarded by Covered California for what looks like a rather astounding string of failures.

Enrollment in the state exchange climbed only about 1% this year, leaving it 300,000 below Lee's goal of 1.7 million. And because the exchange relies on enrollment fees to operate, low sign-ups put the exchange in financial jeopardy.

According to Covered California's proposed budget, released in May, it expects to run an operating deficit of $98 million next fiscal year, and $41 million the year after that. And those numbers assume the exchange can wring 21% out of its budget over the next two years while sharply increasing enrollment.
Lee himself admitted in December that there are questions about the "long-term sustainability of the organization."

We also recently learned, thanks to former CBS News investigative reporter Sharyl Attkisson, that Covered California suffered from "gross incompetence and mismanagement" as it was getting started. Attkisson reported her findings in a two-part piece on the Daily Signal.

This May, the Columbia Journalism Review called for "stronger (media) coverage of Covered California" because of the challenges it's facing and because it's the "largest state-run health insurance exchange."
To top things off, consumers give Covered California an overall one-star rating on Yelp.
Does any of this seem deserving of a raise? Or bonus?

ObamaCare cheerleaders once held up California as a model of success. It certainly is a model of something.Government Work: Enrollment in Covered California was flat this year, and consumers hate it. But the director still got a huge raise and a fat bonus. So much for ObamaCare rooting out health care waste.The 1.4 million who signed up for an ObamaCare plan through Covered California, and who are paying a $13.95 fee every month for the privilege, might be interested to learn that Executive Director Peter Lee just got a 26.8% raise, plus a $65,000 bonus, which is bigger than the $53,000 bonus he received last year.To put this in perspective, Lee's base salary of $333,120 is 49% higher than the average health insurance CEO in the country, and 69% higher than all the CEOs in California, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data.We don't begrudge people for being well compensated for their success. But in this case, Lee is being rewarded by Covered California for what looks like a rather astounding string of failures.Enrollment in the state exchange climbed only about 1% this year, leaving it 300,000 below Lee's goal of 1.7 million. And because the exchange relies on enrollment fees to operate, low sign-ups put the exchange in financial jeopardy.According to Covered California's proposed budget, released in May, it expects to run an operating deficit of $98 million next fiscal year, and $41 million the year after that. And those numbers assume the exchange can wring 21% out of its budget over the next two years while sharply increasing enrollment.Lee himself admitted in December that there are questions about the "long-term sustainability of the organization."We also recently learned, thanks to former CBS News investigative reporter Sharyl Attkisson, that Covered California suffered from "gross incompetence and mismanagement" as it was getting started. Attkisson reported her findings in a two-part piece on the Daily Signal.This May, the Columbia Journalism Review called for "stronger (media) coverage of Covered California" because of the challenges it's facing and because it's the "largest state-run health insurance exchange."To top things off, consumers give Covered California an overall one-star rating on Yelp.Does any of this seem deserving of a raise? Or bonus?ObamaCare cheerleaders once held up California as a model of success. It certainly is a model of something.

Shampoo tycoon Paula Kent Meehan chased silver-screen dreams. Then her star bubble burst. "After painfully coming to the conclusion Hollywood wasn't going to make me the next Joan Crawford, I wanted to control my own destiny," she said.Meehan (1931-2014) ended up turning heads in the business world.With $3,000 earned from acting jobs — equivalent to $23,500 today — she launched hair-care startup Redken Laboratories in 1961. The shampoo firm lathered industry stalwarts like Clairol and took 20% of the U.S. hair-care market by 1980.In 1993, Meehan sold the firm — which tallied $165 million in sales that year — to a L'Oreal (LRLCY) American subsidiary for an undisclosed sum."Although Paula Kent Meehan did not achieve her ambition to be a Hollywood star, she launched one of the most influential American beauty startups of the 1960s and 1970s," Geoffrey Jones, author of "Beauty Imagined: A History of the Global Beauty Industry," told IBD.Meehan restyled the industry by applying highbrow science to hair care products. The company's concoctions — formulated by partner and chemist Jheri Redding — promised to make tresses healthier."Simultaneously, she decided not to compete with incumbents in department stores and drugstores, but instead sell directly to the professional salon channel," said Jones.That move elevated the role of stylists, whom Meehan trained to market her wares. Competitors rushed to copy the approach.Good Look"It's a model of how a crowded and quite mature market can be shifted and reshaped by a new entrepreneurial entrant," Jones said.As a businesswoman, Meehan shone. "Paula Kent was a truly inspiring woman who transformed the hair care industry," said Shane Wolf, Redken Worldwide general manager. "With her great passion and entrepreneurial spirit, she touched the hearts and minds of so many people."Meehan led the firm for decades — partner Redding sold his stake in the mid-1960s and launched competing firms — and maintained a high profile in business and philanthropy until her death at age 82."Like any company, Redken had its ups and downs but never once experienced a losing year, so we had a good reputation on Wall Street," she told the Beverly Hills Courier.She was born Paula Baer in that Los Angeles enclave to accountant Richard Baer and housewife Lois.The California girl began acting at age 12 and dropped out of school at 15 to marry beau Donald Slocum.A divorced mother by age 17, Paula made ends meet as a secretary, gas station attendant and actress. Her stage name: Paula Kent.She appeared in commercials and won bit parts in TV shows, peaking with a recurring role as a restaurant hatcheck girl on the 1960s detective show "77 Sunset Strip.""Like every actress, I had to spend many hours with studio makeup artists and hairdressers," she recalled.Unlike other actresses, she had allergic reactions to hair products. So she turned to a friend's husband, Redding, who owned a beauty salon in Van Nuys, Calif."More than strictly being a beautician, he was actually a frustrated chemist who knew all about the ingredients contained in the products being put on people's hair," Meehan said.His formulations eliminated allergic reactions and made hair healthier because he matched the suds' pH — or measure of hydrogen vs. hydroxide ion levels — to the hair's acidic pH level, which made locks stronger and shinier.Hence the oft-marketed phrase "pH balanced."With Redding's concoctions, Meehan looked beautiful without breaking out in itchy bumps.On the hunch that other women would benefit, the duo launched Redken Laboratories — taking Red from Redding and ken from Kent — in 1961."My primary motivation selfishly was not only to find natural and gentle products suitable for my own hair and skin, since what I'd come across wasn't doing the trick, but also be in a business that would help others," Meehan said.The first batches were mixed in a bathtub with a rowing oar and dubbed with lab-inspired names: Amino Pon and PPT S-77.The solutions seemed unconventional. Redken's shampoo didn't lather, and the conditioner would turn hair brittle if overused.The need to educate beauticians on how to properly apply the products turned into a marketing boon."We began to pioneer the teaching of the chemistry of hair to stylists so they could be better equipped to serve their clients' needs," Meehan said. "In effect, this served to elevate the art of hairdressing to a higher technical and professional standard."Come On InThe in-salon retailing approach became the new style."Salons began to realize that it was crazy not to sell a woman shampoo. She was going to buy it someplace," Meehan said in a 1984 interview with Forbes.Her pioneering paid off. Redken's sales hit $1.5 million in 1966, or $11 million in today's money.For a promotional push, Meehan pursued a big name to expound on her shampoos and conditioners. The one-time aspiring actress understood celebrity power and went after the biggest in hair: French stylist Vidal Sassoon.When he spoke, women listened."I never thought I'd pay anyone what I paid Vidal," Meehan told Modern Salon magazine. "I was shocked at the expense, but I was also shocked at the numbers of people who turned up to see him."Meehan knew how to attract good people.She hired John Meehan as a vice president of sales in 1969 and married him in 1971.The opposites achieved professional balance."John Meehan was a buttoned-down kind of guy with a very low tolerance for risk, and my mother was an entrepreneur who took a lot of risks," Michael Miller, Paula's son from a previous marriage, told Modern Salon. "John was analytic; she was creative. But the two of them together were able to do great things for the industry and for themselves."Great things were happening for the future Mrs. Meehan.In 1970, the company was operating out of a 20,000-square-foot building in Van Nuys, and she was invited to join a local bank's board.The experience let the entrepreneur rub shoulders with some of California's top businessmen and emboldened her to expand.ExpansionRedken's 1971 initial public offering raised $5 million, with which Meehan built a 250,000-square-foot headquarters, manufacturing plant and research facility in L.A.'s Canoga Park neighborhood. The added capacity helped the firm expand distribution to 35 countries.The hair care industry, meanwhile, became a scientific arms race as competitors vied to outformulate each other."One thing we never scrimped on was research. It was an ongoing effort by a large staff," Meehan told the Beverly Hills Courier.Her company would hold more than 80 patents, and the enterprising executive who'd taken night classes in business became an evangelizing chairwoman who shared her enthusiasm with employees and distributors."By 1988 and sales of $120 million, I had enough of being a public entity and decided to take the company private again," Meehan said.With a personally guaranteed $58 million loan, Meehan bought back the company's publicly owned shares in 1988. By 1993, sales had soared to $165 million.The company had long turned away suitors such as Revlon (REV) and Helene Curtis. But after 32 years of business, Meehan accepted a purchase offer from Cosmair, the U.S. licensee of cosmetics giant L'Oreal.Meehan didn't rest after the sale, instead remaining active in business and philanthropy.She helped launch an annual industry recognition event called the Global Salon Business Awards and purchased the Beverly Hills Courier a few months before her death.Meehan simply went after what she wanted, said son Michael: "She had a drive and appetite that far exceeded her experience."

Half the public now supports sending ground troops to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria as support for President Obama's strategy deteriorates, the latest IBD/TIPP poll finds.This stunning finding highlights the growing concern about the recent successes of IS, including the fall of Ramadi in Iraq and Palmyra in Syria, both of which occurred before the survey started.The poll, which was conducted last week, found that 50% now back sending ground troops into Iraq and Syria, while 44% oppose it. Last September, just 42% supported ground troops to fight IS, while 52% were opposed.Even among Democrats, support has gone from 19% last September to 32% in the latest poll.These results come despite Obama's repeated claims that his strategy is working, his pledge not to send ground troops into this fight and the public's perceived war weariness with the Middle East.But the poll shows that Americans are deeply concerned about IS, with 75% saying the group poses "a serious and direct threat to the American homeland." That view is shared across all demographic, political and ideological groups.And 80% believe the Islamic State's use of social media to recruit Americans poses a real threat to the country.The majority also see the loss of Ramadi as an indication of "a weak U.S. strategy" — 69% say this. Just 21% buy the White House spin that it was just "part of the ups and downs of warfare."The poll also finds the public less convinced that Obama has a clear plan to defeat IS than previously: Just 17% say he does, down from 21% when the same question was asked in March. Nearly three quarters (73%) say Obama doesn't have a clear plan, up from 63% in March.In addition, just 26% think the U.S. and its allies are winning the war against IS, while 70% say they aren't. Those numbers have deteriorated slightly since February.However, two-thirds of the public remain upbeat that the U.S. will "eventually succeed" in defeating IS. While this belief is held more strongly by Democrats (73% of whom say IS will be defeated), more than half of the Republicans surveyed (59%) also have a positive outlook in this regard.

The stock market takes a lot of flak for being impersonal. Arguments for or against automated trading aside, stocks are bought and sold by people. People manage and staff publicly traded companies that sell goods and services to, you guessed it, other people.In the end, it's all very personal.Many times, successful investors are buying into visionary leaders as much as they are the actual companies. This is true for many when it comes to Facebook's (FB) Mark Zuckerberg, Tesla's (TSLA) Elon Musk or the omnipotent aura of Apple's (AAPL) Steve Jobs. In other cases, the leaders have less star power but carry a solid background with successful companies.That's why every investor's fundamental research regimen should include a look at a target company's executive management. It takes only a few minutes to get a general sense of who you are dealing with.Chase down a company's annual 10-K Securities & Exchange Commission filing. These forms, as well as profiles on the company's website, list executive management and detail their experience. If it's a young company, look for the 424b prospectus filed prior to the initial offering.Do quick searches of the executives by reading past articles in IBD's The New America and Internet & Technology sections. Get some sense of where the executives came from and what their accomplishments and failures are.A search for news on the Web is also important, because 10-Ks won't tell you an executive's failings.Brilliant inventors, creators and visionary thinkers often make lousy executives. In contrast, some of the best managers have climbed the ranks amid difficult circumstances. They understand a company and its markets from the customer level up.Are there any managers to watch today?Consider the new McDonald's (MCD) CEO, Steve Easterbrook. He took the management helm in March and announced a vast restructuring and turnaround strategy at the beginning of May.Easterbrook is a Brit who was an accountant with PricewaterhouseCoopers before shifting to a management position with McDonald's in London in 1993. He earned the company's top management slot, first in the U.K., then in Europe. He left for several years to run London-based restaurant chains PizzaExpress and Wagamama.Easterbrook re-upped with McDonald's in 2013, earning the title of global chief brand officer.McDonald's shares jumped 5% in late January on news of Easterbrook's appointment, then rose another 8% over the next five weeks. They've been basing since early March as investors wait to see whether Easterbrook proves to be a genuine force for change.Yahoo's (YHOO) Marissa Mayer is not a brand-new CEO, but her task is no less Herculean.She joined Google (GOOGL) in 1999 as the company's 20th employee and first female engineer. She helped build the company, had ups and downs, and notched notable successes, but she had no real experience outside the Google cocoon or as the ultimate decider atop the management heap.Yahoo shares have risen 231% since Mayer took the CEO post in July 2012. But the stock is down 15% so far this year.

Earlier this year, the Obama administration boasted that well over 11 million people had signed up for an ObamaCare plan by the end of the second open enrollment period.

Of course, "signing up" and "paying up" are two different things, which is why the 8 million-plus "sign-ups" Obama was bragging about at the start of last year had dwindled to 6.3 million by year's end.
So now, the White House is saying that 10.2 million have "effectuated" coverage for 2015, which means that they've at least managed to pay their first premium.
This number basically met the goal that the White House set for itself last fall, so it is supposed to be a big achievement.
Except it's not.
Just this January, the Congressional Budget Office projected that enrollment would be 12 million for 2015. And a year ago, it had forecast 13 million ObamaCare enrollees.
A little bit of math shows that sign-ups in 2015 came in 22% below the CBO's earlier forecast.
And that's not factoring in the many who likely drop out of ObamaCare during the year. (Between September and December last year, enrollment dropped by about 400,000.)

Meanwhile, the CBO still thinks ObamaCare will manage to more than double enrollment in 2016 to 21 million. That already seemed like a stretch, given that it would mean more than doubling enrollment in one year, even though the gain was far less this year.
It seems even less likely now, given the kind of double-digit rate increases that insurance companies are asking for.
Measuring ObamaCare's success is starting to look a little bit like a game of Limbo.

In an unusual move, Chinese nuclear scientists have warned their U.S. counterparts they have significantly increased their intelligence estimates of North Korea's nuclear weapons capabilities far past American figures.The ominous disclosure, first reported by the Wall Street Journal, is alarming because, since North Korea's first weapons test in 2006, China's scientists have consistently produced weapons estimates far under those of the U.S.Now, however, the Chinese believe the poor hermit kingdom atop the Korean Peninsula may already have as many as 20 nuclear warheads, according to the compelling Journal story. And possess the capability to double that number within the next year.The information could hardly come at a worse time for President Obama, who's currently leading talks with Iran over a controversial incomplete pact once designed to prohibit that country from developing nuclear weapons.Now, however, the evolving document reportedly settles for delaying Iran's development of such weapons of mass destruction, subject to contested versions of international inspections. But North Korea already has nuclear weapons.The implications for American diplomacy and security are serious globally and within northeast Asia, where South Korea and Japan, like Iran's Middle Eastern neighbors such as Saudi Arabia, could be expected to start a nuclear arms race in their own defense.Under existing treaties, an attack on South Korea or Japan would be considered an attack on the United States.And while Iran's nascent intercontinental ballistic missile development program is not part of the current negotiations, North Korea is already believed to have such a missile capable of delivering a warhead some 5,600 miles away.If operational, such a missile would put the entire Middle East with its vast energy resources, most of Europe and the northwestern third of the U.S. within range, including much of California.And, of course, such rogue nations might be tempted to sell or give a nuclear weapon to terrorists for use or blackmail.While Obama declares that all options, including military action, remain on the table regarding Iran, his actions and inactions, such as his empty red-line threat in Syria or vows to end Russia's annexation of Crimea, hold little credibility. He hasn't even permitted provisions of defensive weapons to the embattled government of Ukraine.According to the Journal's analysis, "The (revised) Chinese estimates reflect growing concern in Beijing over North Korea's weapons program and what they see as U.S. inaction ... ."Of course, the Chinese estimates could also be designed as distractions from China's own aggressive military moves, for instance, constructing new offshore bases.The new estimates also have potential domestic political impacts as the U.S. presidential campaign gets underway.They would elevate the importance of foreign affairs in the GOP primary debate, which would play to the strengths of some candidates, like Sen. Marco Rubio of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, while possibly hurting the arguments of others, including governors rarely as conversant in diplomacy and military affairs.Such legacy threats could also damage Hillary Clinton's bid to overcome history and win a third consecutive Democrat White House term. She was secretary of State for 65% of Obama's presidency, including the Benghazi murders and Libya's descent into terrorist chaos.A new CNN/ORC Poll published last Wednesday found Americans are also focused on the Middle East — but not Iran. The survey of 1,018 adults said 68% of them see ISIS as a very serious threat. This compares with 39% who say that about Iran, 25% about Russia and 18% on China.North Korea is seen as a very serious threat by less than a third of adults (32%). Malcolm is IBD's national politics columnist at Investors.com/Andrew Malcolm.

Waste: After spending billions on state-run ObamaCare exchanges, the federal government is only now writing clear rules on how that money can be spent, while half of the exchanges head toward bankruptcy.state-run exchanges were supposed to form the beating heart of ObamaCare. And the Obama administration dumped almost $5 billion in an effort to make it a reality.The results have been a disaster.Of the 37 states that received $2.1 billion in grants to establish an exchange, only 17 did so, and they got an additional $2.7 billion from the feds.Of those 17, two went bankrupt in the first year. One of them, Oregon, had received a $60 million "early innovator grant." Residents of those states now use the federal Healthcare.gov site.A memo from Health and Human Services' Inspector General Daniel Levinson warns that some of the remaining may be violating federal law in an effort to stay afloat.ObamaCare told the states that they'd get plenty of federal money to help them set up their exchanges — but not run them. And starting this year, the state exchanges had to be self-financing — they had to pay their own way out of exchange fees or other funding sources.Any federal grant money left over could be used only for things other than operations and maintenance.As the IG explains, the rules on what these states can spend federal money on are vague, and as a result the exchanges "might have used, and might continue to use, establishment grant funds for operating expenses."Washington's exchange, it found, has plans to spend $4 million of its remaining federal grant money on printing, postage and bank fees.The IG characterized this is "a significant matter" that requires "immediate attention."Responding to this urgent memo, Sens. Orrin Hatch and Chuck Grassley pressed the administration to respond to this issue, and were told the administration would do so "soon."Meanwhile, the Washington Post reports that half of the remaining state exchanges face serious financial problems as they wrestle "with surging costs, especially for balky technology and expensive customer call centers — and tepid enrollment numbers."Minnesota's user fees, for example, will cover just a quarter of its cost next fiscal year. Washington state's exchange faces a $4.5 million deficit.Enrollment gains won't help.The 15 remaining state exchanges saw sign-ups climb 12% this year.But that includes huge enrollment jumps in Maryland and Massachusetts, both of which suffered massive technical problems and enrolled a tiny number in ObamaCare's first year. Absent those two state, sign-ups climbed just 7.5%.In California, which faces an $80 million deficit, enrollment barely budged.The federal exchange is hardly in better shape. The administration has poured more than $2 billion over the past four years into building the Healthcare.gov exchange, according to a Bloomberg analysis, and even now it remains half built.The SHOP exchanges ObamaCare set up for millions of eligible small businesses are failing as well.A Government Accountability Office found enrollment was "significantly lower than expected." Just 2,000 businesses signed up in California, for example, and only 72 did so in Washington.The Obama administration hasn't bothered to release sign-up data for the federal SHOP exchange.Obama sold his overhaul as a way to bring greater efficiency and discipline to the health care market. As evidenced by the exchanges it created, the exact opposite is occurring.Today, thanks to ObamaCare, there's more waste, more bloat and more needless bureaucracy in the health care system than ever.

Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.
After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.
On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.
Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) plunged 15% in premarket trade following disappointing earnings for Q3 and a weak outlook. The retailer posted adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $1.64 billion. Views were for EPS of 47 cents on sales of $1.64 billion. The retailer guided Q4 earnings at $1.10 to $1.25 a share vs. views for $1.43. On Monday, shares fell to their lowest levels since January 2012.

Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.Stock futures pointed to a strong open Tuesday amid strength in most overseas markets. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 17 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures climbed 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64 points.Stocks reversed higher Monday to solid gains, but volume was lower.Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.In stocks, Home Depot (HD) rallied 3% in premarket trading in the stock market today after beating views. The home improvement retailer posted Q3 earnings of $1.35 a share on sales of $21.8 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.32 on revenue of $21.76 billion. It also pegged full-year earnings at $5.36 a share or a nickel above views.Rival Lowe's (LOW) was also up 3% in premarket trading. It reports quarterly results Wednesday.Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 2% in the premarket despite posting mixed quarterly results. The world's biggest retailer reported fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.03 a share. But excluding a gain from leases, earnings were 99 cents a share. Sales came in at $117.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $117.79 billion.Fitbit (FIT) gained more than 2% in premarket activity after being upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank Of America/Merrill Lynch. With nine months still to go before actual nominee selection begins, the 2016 presidential field is still unfolding.Today, Mike Huckabee jumps in again, one day after Carly Fiorina joined the GOP contest and after Sen. Don Quixote, er, Bernie Sanders, announced he's taking on presumptive Democrat nominee Hillary Clinton.Mrs. Clinton herself is back in Las Vegas today for another of her patented patent citizen roundtables, this one on immigration. (Watch the Huckabee kickoff from Hope, Arkansas on C-SPAN at 11a.m. and the Clinton Vegas event at 5:45p.m., both Eastern Time.) Perhaps more importantly, though, a new Wall Street Journal / NBC News Poll is out. Most polls this early merely reflect name recognition. But this one provides revealing insights to the evolving thinking of Republicans, Democrats and the most important group of all come fall 2016, independents.You can read the entire Journal poll story here. Our takeaways of the most interesting lessons follow:1) From a broad electorate point of view, Clinton's campaign roll-out since April 12 has been a disaster, thanks to all the negative attention to her family foundation's shady fundraising and ongoing questions about her illegal email server as secretary of State.Those with negative views of her jumped from 36% to 42% in just one month. While those believing in her honesty sank from 38% last summer to barely 25% now. Not a good trend coming after the tumultuous era of questionable ethics under Obama.2) But among Democrats, Clinton is Teflon. Fully 86% see her as sufficiently knowledgeable and experienced to take over the Oval Office, while barely 14% don't trust her. This is great in primary/caucus season.3) However, among swing voters, that vital segment necessary to capture enough electoral votes, signs of serious trouble for Clinton. Those independents with a negative view of her soared from one-third (34%) to nearly one-half (48%) -- in only a month.4) Clinton retains quite strong support among women, where in individual, hypothetical match-ups she outdraws four potential Republican opponents. You'll never guess who does best against her though? The eye doctor, Rand Paul, who did particularly well against her among independents.5) Among Republican primary voters, Jeb Bush retains his lead in the fractured field with 23% support, followed by Marco Rubio at 18%, the unannounced Scott Walker with 14% and Paul and Ted Cruz tied at 11%.But hidden in those responses is a revealing stat. The candidate whom most Republicans could see themselves eventually supporting, regardless of their current favorite, is Marco Rubio. Watch this one in coming months.Finally, a warning for any Wisconsin governor who didn't finish his studies at Marquette University. Walker may want to take those last few credits online in coming months. Because nearly two-thirds of voters say they'd have reservations supporting someone as commander-in-chief with no college degree.RELATED:How long can Hillary dodge media questions?Can Hillary Clinton survive her role in the Benghazi murders?The first backer of Hillary Clinton from 2008 dumps her this timeHillary Clinton wants constitutional limits on free speech of others

But if a woman makes 19 or 20 mistakes, she's a tramp!" Relax, it meant, because there would be no pretense, no front, no earnestness. This was going to…
FedEx's (FDX) fiscal third-quarter sales and profit grew vs. the same quarter last year, but sales came in lower than expected and the company also expects earnings growth to weaken this quarter.
Earnings per share minus one-time items for the No. 2 U.S. package shipper jumped 63% to $2.01, its best growth in three years, beating estimates by 14 cents a share.
Revenue grew 3.5% to $11.7 billion, missing views for $11.79 billion. The company recorded strong sales gains across all segments and earlier reported healthy holiday sales.
Chief Financial Officer Alan Graf Jr. said the company expects "to deliver record fourth quarter and fiscal year earnings."
FedEx said it "assumes continued moderate global economic growth," which would likely result in higher shipments this year.
But FedEx also issued cautious full-year earnings guidance of $8.80 to $8.95 per diluted share, citing currency headwinds. Wall Street expected $8.97.
The Memphis-based shipper's guidance implies Q4 EPS of $2.78, far below Wall Street consensus for $2.86.
No. 1 shipper UPS (UPS) also warned in January of lower earnings this year, citing rising pension expenses and currency headwinds.

FedEx shares gapped down and were trading off 2.4% by early afternoon trading in the stock market today. The stock fell below its 50-day moving average, but is still in a flat base going back to Dec. 8.
UPS shares were down less than 1% intrday.
Like other global companies, FedEx is taking a hit from the strengthening dollar, which shrinks the value of overseas revenue.
That's expected to be offset somewhat this quarter by lower fuel prices and rising shipments because the West Coast ports slowdown has forced some companies to turn to air and land shipping.

By segment, FedEx Freight revenue grew 6% in Q3 to $1.43 billion. Ground shipment revenue was up 12% at $3.39 billion, and Express shipping revenue was about flat at $6.66 billion, vs. $6.67 billion in the same quarter a year ago.

FedEx stock has been consolidating for more than two months, even though earning growth generally accelerated. Over the last four quarters, earnings growth climbed from 15% to 37%, 36% and 63% last quarter.
Its stock carries a respectable 81 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it has outperformed 81% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The bulls failed to mount a counter-attack to Tuesday's sell-off, and stocks finished mildly lower Wednesday in light trading. The Nasdaq fell less than 0.1%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 0.3% in the stock market today. Volume on both exchanges was lighter than Monday, according to preliminary data.
Volkswagen (VLKAY) jumped nearly 7% as its board accepted the resignation of CEO Martin Winterkorn in the wake of a scandal over cheating on emissions tests. The stock is still down 25% this week.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 36 were higher and 14 were lower. The top performer was AMN Healthcare Services (AHS), up more than 3% to a new high. The company, which supplies health care facilities with doctors and nurses, announced the acquisition of First String Healthcare.
Egg Producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM), another IBD 50 name, rose nearly 3%. It's building the right side of a base.
Another provider of nurses and doctors, Cross Country Healthcare (CCRN), rose nearly 4% in above-average volume to a new high.

Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR) fell 11% in monster volume. An analyst reportedly said the company might lose Verizon (VZ) as a cloud customer. For Old Dominion Freight Line, the less-than-truckload carrier, logistics and freight-forwarding company, 2014 turned out to be the proverbial perfect storm.

Industry capacity constraints, supply disruptions, the growing economy and the company's strong execution all contributed to excellent results for the North Carolina firm, said analyst Todd Fowler of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

One year of double-digit earnings and sales growth does not necessarily make a best-in-class operator, but Old Dominion's (ODFL) strength goes much further back. It has at least a decade of strong results under its belt with only one year of noticeable decline in profit and sales, as the recession's effects were being felt in 2009. Even then, it still registered a profit vs. many of its peers.

"They've been very consistent with how they've run their network, which has allowed them to generate very high incremental margins on additional tonnage or additional price that they're giving," said Fowler. "They are very focused on the cost side of the business and they continue to invest in technology, which allows them to improve efficiencies across the board."

Old Dominion focuses on less-than-truckload, or LTL, transport. This means that multiple shipments are usually contained on a truck, which then delivers the goods to one of its 225 service centers for distribution to clients. The firm operates in the national as well as regional markets. It also has been expanding its worldwide freight forwarding services.
Mover In The Market

The company's stellar business performance is reflected in its market performance. Old Dominion stock jumped 46% last year, while investors who had held on to the shares for a decade could benefit from a nearly 600% gain.

It's the highest-rated company in IBD's Transportation-Truck industry group, which includes 20 stocks. And it's second largest by market cap, after J.B. Hunt Transport (JBHT) . Swift Transportation (SWFT) is third in size.

Old Dominion was founded in 1934 by current CEO David Congdon's grandparents, with a single truck running between Richmond, Va., and Norfolk, Va. Congdon became president and chief operating officer in 1997. Currently, Old Dominion operates its service centers across most of the U.S. and runs more than 6,400 tractors and 19,400 trailers.

In addition to serving national markets, Old Dominion also set a goal of operating in the regional, interregional and long-haul markets, all under one corporate office and computer system, Congdon says.

The company has been successful in competing with small regional players as well as national carriers within the U.S. It also expanded its reach outside of the lower 48 states to Canada, Mexico, Alaska, Hawaii and the Caribbean. Partnerships in global freight forwarding have provided Old Dominion access to China and other international markets.

Old Dominion notes that it holds a 5% to 6% market share in the LTL industry, as estimated by an independent market research firm. The company plans to double this number within the next couple of years.

The carrier has one of the industry's lowest cargo claim ratios. "Historically, the LTL industry has had a cargo claim ratio of 1% to 1.5% of revenue," Congdon told IBD. "We have driven ours down this year to in the range of 0.3% to 0.35%."

Several elements contributed to low claims. Those include logistics racks in all trailers to avoid shifting of shipment within the trucks during transportation, the use of airbags between cargo, the use of straps and more.
But the most important tool, said Congdon, is getting the employees to use these tools.
"You can invest all you want in all the tools," he said. "But until you get employees believing in what they should be doing every day, that's the biggest key to the success."

That said, the company has put a substantial amount of investment into its operations and infrastructure in the past decade. This trend is expected to continue in the next several years as it plans to take a larger slice of the LTL market.

"It's going to be a combination of growth capex, investing in technology and improving their existing infrastructure for when they get to bottlenecks or points that they've outgrown the existing infrastructure that they had in place," said Fowler.
What About Oil Prices?
Old Dominion also has a track record of effectively managing the expense side of operations.
With oil prices slashed to less than half of what they were just six months ago, analysts expect fuel-cost savings to be largely passed through to the customers.

The trucking industry has traditionally operated with fuel price surcharges that adjust on a weekly basis, and Fowler doesn't expect to see a big tail wind or headwind for the company from the changing price of fuel.

"What we're more focused on is the indirect impact of what's happening with changes in end markets from the standpoint that the oil and gas related to the drilling activity has consumed a lot of freight capacity," he said. "If we see those end markets slow, that could free up some capacity overall in the industry."
However, counterbalancing it would be the benefits consumers would receive from lower fuel costs, according to Fowler.
"Typically when we think about freight activity in general, it's probably two-thirds consumer oriented and one-third manufacturing," he noted.
Net-net, Fowler expects a modest benefit from lower fuel costs on the expense side.

Additional risks for the company include some increased competition. While the cost and barriers of entry to this business are quite steep for traditional players, the entrance of technology-based truck brokerages has created some competition by providing more favorable cost to smaller customers, explained Fowler.
Large companies such as FedEx (FDX) and UPS (UPS) also have their own LTL business, which gives price advantages in bundling various services.
"One of the big industry issues is the driver shortage," said Congdon. "There are fewer people growing up and saying 'Hey, I want to be a truck driver.'"
Drivers Wanted
Congdon estimates that today the industry is short about 50,000 to 60,000 drivers. This figure is expected to surpass 200,000 in the next decade.
"The good news for our company is ... we have a fertile soil to grow our drivers," he said.

Old Dominion offers competitive pay for people who can start working on its docks, without having to have college education. They can then transition into becoming drivers for pay topping $60,000 a year and sometimes as high as $100,000.

The company reports its 2014 fourth-quarter and year-end results on Feb. 5, before trading opens. Analyst consensus as polled by Thomson Reuters calls for sales of $717 million and $2.78 billion for each period respectively. Earnings per share are forecast to be $0.72 and $3.02, with EPS growth of 26% for 2014. Eric Fischman and Matt Sabel, co-managers of MFS Growth Fund , are road warriors. To find the stock investment ideas with durable growth that they seek, they see dozens of companies each week, Sabel says. And that means frequent travel. Sabel says he's on about 80 flights a year, traveling up to half of each month. "It's worth it," Sabel…
In the age of text messages, talking with someone over the phone seems as quaint as sending a fax.
Online and mobile food ordering company GrubHub (GRUB) is betting on the demise of the phone call.
"Ten years from now is anybody going to pick up the phone and order food?" asks Adam DeWitt, chief financial officer of GrubHub.

GrubHub has a lot at stake in seeing the phone call's passing. It's the largest online and mobile food ordering company in the U.S. And it wants to keep it that way as people turn to smartphones to conduct their everyday lives.

GrubHub, based in Chicago, was founded in 2004 by two Web developers, one of them its CEO, Matt Maloney. In 2013 it merged with chief rival Seamless and in April 2014 went public, at an offering price of 26.
Hungry investors bid up GrubHub stock 31% from the IPO price on the first trading day. After some ups and downs, shares ended the year at 36.32. GrubHub stock is up 16% so far this year.
Restaurant Receipts Rack Up
GrubHub's platforms let Web and mobile users order takeout food from 30,000 restaurants in more than 800 cities in the U.S., plus London.
At year-end, more than 5 million active diners used GrubHub's platforms to order takeout food, 40% more than a year earlier.
"Once they've tried it, customers become very sticky and GrubHub becomes a way of life for them," DeWitt said in an interview with IBD.
On a typical day in the fourth quarter, GrubHub sent more than 200,000 orders per day to restaurant partners.
Analyst Kevin Kopelman of Cowen and Co. notes that GrubHub has "one of the best business models in local Internet and a powerful competitive lead."

GrubHub figures that its addressable market for takeout food is around $70 billion. That includes food sales from independent restaurants and pizza parlors, but excludes large pizza chains, high-end restaurants and cafeterias and their like on the low end.

In Q4, GrubHub processed $508 million in gross food sales, up 37% from the prior year. That put the company on path for an annual run rate of around $2 billion. Even at $2 billion, GrubHub's market share would be only around 3%.

So there is still a lot of untapped potential, DeWitt says, even in its strongest markets, such as Chicago, New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., San Francisco and Los Angeles. (In New York, GrubHub mostly promotes under the regional brand Seamless.)

"We're in most of the markets we want to be in. The question is how deep we're in them. We could easily double the amount of business we do without adding a single restaurant, by driving new diners to those restaurants," DeWitt said.
How? He ticked off everything from social media and search engine optimization to radio, TV and banner ads in buses and subways.
GrubHub spent $19 million on sales and marketing in the fourth quarter and $66.2 million for the full year, up from $12.4 million and $48.3 million, respectively, a year earlier.
How Does GrubHub Work?

GrubHub customers can choose from a list of popular takeout options near their homes or offices. Once they decide on what they want, GrubHub transmits their orders to restaurants for fulfillment and delivery.
GrubHub's average commission on an order is 14.5%. Restaurants can bid up commissions for better placement on GrubHub's search website.
When GrubHub looks to sign new restaurants, it goes "neighborhood to neighborhood," DeWitt says.
"We can't sign up every restaurant right away because if we push the peddle too hard the restaurants won't get a lot of business from us. So we need to balance growth in each market."
GrubHub's revenue in the fourth quarter jumped 50% from a year earlier to $73.3 million, and on a full-year basis it was up 49% to $253.9 million.
Earnings in Q4 came in at 13 cents per share, up from three cents a year earlier, and topping the consensus view of analysts in a Thomson Reuters poll.
The company guided revenue expectations for 2015 to between $335 million and $350 million.
"Our biggest competition is the paper menu in the drawer," DeWitt said.
But online rivals are circling. In early February, consumer-reviews website Yelp (YELP) acquired Eat24, viewed as GrubHub's closest rival, for $134 million.
The deal "likely marks a more competitive era in U.S. food delivery," wrote Kopelman in a research note. Nevertheless, he added, "GrubHub remains in the driver's seat."
Analyst Ralph Schackart of William Blair thinks there could be some fallout for GrubHub longer term.
"If consumer habits change and users begin to view Yelp as a place to transact rather than review, Yelp will be well positioned to gain market share from GrubHub," Schackart wrote.

He noted that Yelp has 135 million unique visitors and 1 million U.S. restaurants listed on its website and mobile app. But he also noted that such a shift from reviews to transactions is not occurring at a "meaningful pace" and that Eat24's revenue is a fraction of GrubHub's.
Eat24 was already a partner of Yelp, so the deal will essentially allow Yelp to retain the full transaction fee rather than splitting it, Schackart said.

Meanwhile, GrubHub will be digesting two new acquisitions of its own, both delivery companies. One, Boston-based DiningIn, was acquired in early February and another, Restaurants on the Run, which is big on the West Coast, is expected to close soon.
Driving To An Uber Model?
Restaurant partners usually handle deliveries, but GrubHub has been testing in-house deliveries in several cities. But DeWitt says in-house deliveries remain a small part of its overall business.

Kopelman notes that GrubHub's expanded delivery logistics business could "re-accelerate growth" in the number of its restaurant partners by adding eateries that previously did not offer delivery. He noted GrubHub's restaurant additions slowed in 2014 vs. 2013.
The move into delivery logistics is also a defensive move in the face of up and coming food delivery operations in various local markets, he noted.
Among them are Delivery Dudes in South Florida, ride-sharing car service Uber's uberFresh in L.A. and San Francisco-based Caviar, which focuses on high-end restaurants in several major cities.
Another contender is Postmates, a delivery service that uses local couriers to buy and deliver food or goods from restaurants and stores in several cities.
Even Amazon (AMZN) has entered the restaurant food delivery race. Kopelman calls Amazon's same-day service in Seattle "underwhelming to date."

Amazon does some plan-ahead restaurant delivery via its AmazonFresh service in several cities.In the age of text messages, talking with someone over the phone seems as quaint as sending a fax.Online and mobile food ordering company GrubHub (GRUB) is betting on the demise of the phone call."Ten years from now is anybody going to pick up the phone and order food?" asks Adam DeWitt, chief financial officer of GrubHub.GrubHub has a lot at stake in seeing the phone call's passing. It's the largest online and mobile food ordering company in the U.S. And it wants to keep it that way as people turn to smartphones to conduct their everyday lives.GrubHub, based in Chicago, was founded in 2004 by two Web developers, one of them its CEO, Matt Maloney. In 2013 it merged with chief rival Seamless and in April 2014 went public, at an offering price of 26.Hungry investors bid up GrubHub stock 31% from the IPO price on the first trading day. After some ups and downs, shares ended the year at 36.32. GrubHub stock is up 16% so far this year.Restaurant Receipts Rack UpGrubHub's platforms let Web and mobile users order takeout food from 30,000 restaurants in more than 800 cities in the U.S., plus London.At year-end, more than 5 million active diners used GrubHub's platforms to order takeout food, 40% more than a year earlier."Once they've tried it, customers become very sticky and GrubHub becomes a way of life for them," DeWitt said in an interview with IBD.On a typical day in the fourth quarter, GrubHub sent more than 200,000 orders per day to restaurant partners.Analyst Kevin Kopelman of Cowen and Co. notes that GrubHub has "one of the best business models in local Internet and a powerful competitive lead."GrubHub figures that its addressable market for takeout food is around $70 billion. That includes food sales from independent restaurants and pizza parlors, but excludes large pizza chains, high-end restaurants and cafeterias and their like on the low end.In Q4, GrubHub processed $508 million in gross food sales, up 37% from the prior year. That put the company on path for an annual run rate of around $2 billion. Even at $2 billion, GrubHub's market share would be only around 3%.So there is still a lot of untapped potential, DeWitt says, even in its strongest markets, such as Chicago, New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., San Francisco and Los Angeles. (In New York, GrubHub mostly promotes under the regional brand Seamless.)"We're in most of the markets we want to be in. The question is how deep we're in them. We could easily double the amount of business we do without adding a single restaurant, by driving new diners to those restaurants," DeWitt said.How? He ticked off everything from social media and search engine optimization to radio, TV and banner ads in buses and subways.GrubHub spent $19 million on sales and marketing in the fourth quarter and $66.2 million for the full year, up from $12.4 million and $48.3 million, respectively, a year earlier.How Does GrubHub Work?GrubHub customers can choose from a list of popular takeout options near their homes or offices. Once they decide on what they want, GrubHub transmits their orders to restaurants for fulfillment and delivery.GrubHub's average commission on an order is 14.5%. Restaurants can bid up commissions for better placement on GrubHub's search website.When GrubHub looks to sign new restaurants, it goes "neighborhood to neighborhood," DeWitt says."We can't sign up every restaurant right away because if we push the peddle too hard the restaurants won't get a lot of business from us.
