With just over two weeks left of open enrollment, sign-ups for California's ObamaCare exchange are nearly 200,000 behind last year's total. Unless the pace picks up sharply from the recent sub-30,000 sign-ups per week, it could come up short.

Through Monday, just over 1.2 million had chosen plans -- but not necessarily submitted a payment -- through the Covered California exchange vs. just over 1.4 million in last year's enrollment period.

One reason last year's total is such a high hurdle is because out of those sign-ups, only 1.14 million, or 81%, ever submitted a payment. Still, Covered California set a goal of 1.7 million paid enrollees this year and it doesn't appear that it will come close to that target, even if a last-minute surge materializes.

The explanation for why Covered California projections were apparently so wide of the mark will take time to emerge. The transfer of some 85,000 of last year's paid enrollees to Medi-Cal after they were determined eligible during the renewal process has dampened this year's total, but only modestly. Because the state hasn't released information about the age of people signing up, it's not clear if the shortfall is across the board or concentrated among young adults, which would be a negative for the exchange's future.

While California's premium increases were reportedly quite modest overall, some may have had unpleasant price suprises because of the complicated way ObamaCare determines subsidies. In Los Angeles County, for example, the after-subsidy cost of a bronze plan jumped 25% for a 40-year-old earning 225% of the poverty level ($26,250).
It's possible, too, that more people than expected could be signing up for ObamaCare plans off the exchange, where no subsidies are available.

In any case, because of California's sluggish enrollment, Florida has overtaken it as the state with the most ObamaCare sign-ups: 1.27 million as of Jan. 16.With just over two weeks left of open enrollment, sign-ups for California's ObamaCare exchange are nearly 200,000 behind last year's total. After a chilly third quarter, FedEx (FDX) is expected Wednesday to show that it's been trucking along to Q4 and year-end positives.The shipping company's Q4 earnings should rise 10.8% from a year earlier to $2.36 a share, and revenue is expected to rise 2% to $11.66 billion, according to analyst estimates.For the full year, analysts anticipate FedEx earnings to have increased 7% to $6.67 per share. Sales are expected to have increased 2.5% to $45.4 billion. The fiscal year ended in May.The winter chill had suppressed FedEx's Q3, with earnings flat at $1.23, below estimates. Revenue of $11.3 billion was up 3%.By midafternoon, FedEx shares were trading slightly down in the stock market today, Monday.Last week, the company announced a quarterly cash dividend of 20 cents per share on its common stock, a 5-cent bump up.Rival and market leader UPS (UPS) reported Q1 in April, with per-share earnings falling 5.8% to 98 cents, missing views by a dime. Revenue rose 2.6% to $13.78 billion, but missed estimates. Both companies attributed the winter-quarter misses to the unforgiving weather.UPS shares were flat at 101 by midafternoon.In May, FedEx said it will increase shipping prices. Expect to see FedEx Ground begin to charge all packages by "dimensional weight," starting in January 2015. This means shipments will be charged by volume and weight, and not weight alone, increasing the price for bulky items.The company currently charges by dimensional weight for shipments only 3 cubic feet or larger.FedEx Freight's fuel surcharge was hiked by 3 percentage points at the beginning of June. Including air freight, the company raised FedEx Freight shipping prices by 3.9% in March and increased FedEx Ground and FedEx Home Delivery rates by an average of 4.9% at the start of the year.

The younger crowd may be skittish about moving into the housing market due to sparse financial resources and lack of credit.But it's a different story for Americans age 55 and over. Those who can are jumping into homebuying — selling their existing houses to move into new ones aimed at their age group. Many are at or near retirement, while others are seeking a change in lifestyle — and at this age they can have financial flexibility.Some have reaped hefty gains from the stock market, adding to a nest egg saved over the years. Rising home values in the housing recovery have also given more of them the ability to finally sell, at an appreciated price or at least one that can cover the mortgage.Top homebuilders such as PulteGroup (PHM), Lennar (LEN) and Toll Bros. (TOL) report brisk sales for their active-adult homes and homes that appeal to the 55-plus crowd.Take PulteGroup, which builds the Del Webb brand of active adult communities for adults 55 and over."Consistent with the overall housing market, we have seen sustained improvement in demand for our active adult homes for the past two-plus years," PulteGroup spokesman James Zeumer told IBD via email.Signing Up SalesThe company's active-adult sales lifted from roughly 4,100 homes in 2011 to about 5,300 in 2013. Zeumer says the recovery in active-adult home demand continued into 2014. Sign-ups in the first quarter were up 7% and in the second quarter they rose 11% over a year earlier.One gauge of demand in the single-family 55-plus housing market is the National Association of Home Builders 55+ Housing Market Index. In the second quarter the index increased three points from a year earlier to a level of 56. That's the highest second-quarter reading since the inception of the index in 2008 and the 11th straight quarter of year-over-year improvements.The prognosis for homebuying across all age groups looks improved this summer with Thursday's release of July data on contracts signed to buy existing homes, and that could further bolster the 55-plus group's prospects to sell their old homes.The pending home sales index rose 3.3% from June on a seasonally adjusted basis, though down 2.1% from a year earlier, the National Association of Realtors reported. It's at the highest level since last August and at 105.9 is above the level of 100 considered an average activity level."One of the factors contributing to the positive signs in the 55+ housing market is the slow but steady increase in existing-home sales in the last three months," said NAHB Chief Economist David Crowe in a press release. "The 55+ market is strongly driven by consumers being able to sell their existing homes at a favorable price in order to buy or rent in a 55+ community."Domino Effect AppliesAdds NAHB Director of Economic Services Stephen Melman: "The best thing that could happen for new construction is that the existing-home market improves. Every prospective buyer, like the age 55-plus buyer, has to sell their existing home before they buy a new one. The real key (to the index rise) was the existing-home market."Total existing-home sales lifted 2.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.15 million in July, according to the NAR. Sales notched their highest pace of 2014 and have risen four straight months. But they remain 4.3% below the 5.38 million-unit level last July, the peak of 2013. "Existing-home sales are continuing to move up," said Melman. "But the one caveat is the first-time homebuyer's share (of those sales) was less than 29%. Typically that would be 40%. So existing-home sales are increasing, but the first-time buyer isn't in there full tilt. So it may be the 55-plus (group) buying homes that meet their demand."Sales of new single-family homes fell 2.4% monthly in July, the Commerce Department reported Monday. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales, at 412,000, marked the lowest level since March, although it was a 12.3% rise from last July.Demand for new homes by the 55-plus age group is on the rise.Toll Bros. Active Living is the luxury homebuilders' active-adult division, with single-family homes, condos and town houses. As of April 2014, it accounted for 8% of the company's revenue, says Toll Bros. Group President Chris Gaffney. He says all of Toll Bros.' homebuyers, including the 55 and over active adult group, have been motivated to buy in the past year or so."During this recent downturn, so many people were out of the buying market," Gaffney told IBD. "Now, they've seen their portfolios grow again, and they're extremely interested in making a move because interest rates are still fabulous."Gaffney says there's "plenty of pent-up demand" on part of the active adult buyers following a pullback during the recession, and the "affordability index is quite high when you look at history."These older buyers, he adds, have gotten "tired of putting their lives" on hold in the wake of the recession. " Generally these folks are extremely savvy and successful, they have tremendous FICO (credit) scores, they've built up their portfolios over the years and understand exactly what they want with their lifestyle and what they're looking to do as they move forward in life. ."Melman said by email: "The stronger 55+ market could be put in context of the overall strength of the trade-up market/higher-income buyers, except this group is focused not on larger homes but new homes better designed for their needs. As existing sales slowly increase, more people who put plans on hold can now sell their existing home to finance what they really want for the next ten or twenty years: quality design, low maintenance, accommodations for family."Homes Built To FitMajor homebuilders are luring this group with a raft of amenities.Besides its active adult communities, Lennar offers an option for multigenerational families living under one roof. The "Next Gen" home within a home features a suite with a separate private entrance, bedroom, bathroom, laundry, eat-in kitchenette and living room.Jeff Roos, Western regional president for Lennar, says many buyers want to let their children live in the suite. Since it started making these homes available at the end of 2011, Lennar has sold over 2,000. It has 120 Next Gen communities and more than 50 floor-plan options."The Next Gen is growing every day as we expand across the country," Roos told IBD. "This is the first time a homebuilder came out with a great solution for a multigenerational home. It's the first time (the different generations) can live together, but independently. We're seeing a big movement toward it. Our reception to the product has far exceeded our expectations."Zeumer calls Del Webb homes "perfect for empty-nesters who may be looking to downsize, but not necessarily downgrade the features and finishings of their next home."Options can include big garages, flex spaces, wet bars, hearth rooms, raised dishwashers and sunrooms.
Recovering from a frosty Q3, FedEx (FDX) drove home healthy results as the shipping giant reported fourth-quarter results Wednesday.
Earnings rose 15.5% to $2.46 per share, beating views by a dime, and revenue rose 3.2% to $11.8 billion, topping estimates of $11.66 billion.
FedEx shares jumped nearly 5% to 147 in late morning trade on the stock market today.

A severe winter season hurt FedEx and its main rival, UPS (UPS), in the previous quarter. But FedEx Ground Q4 revenue grew 8% to $3.01 billion, the company said, with 8% average daily volume growth, thanks to e-commerce business shipping goods from Amazon (AMZN), eBay (EBAY) and other online retailers large and small.
FedEx Freight Q4 revenue grew 12% from year-ago figures to $1.55 billion. FedEx Express rose slightly from last year to $7 billion in the most recent quarter, despite challenges from fuel pricing.
For the year ended in May, FedEx revenue rose 3% to $45.6 billion with earnings increasing 8% to $6.75 per share.

The Memphis-based company will hike up FedEx Ground prices in January 2015 as packages are charged by "dimensional weight" — i.e., by volume and weight instead of weight alone. FedEx Freight shipping prices were raised 3.9% in March, and FedEx Ground and FedEx Home Delivery prices were increased by an average of 4.9% at the beginning of 2014. UPS also recently announced similar plans.
The shipping company anticipates fiscal 2015 earnings of $8.50 to $9 per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect $8.75 per share for the year.

"We think (management's) willingness to issue bold guidance (especially the high end at $9) underscores the progress that has been made in turning around the ailing Express business," said Macquarie analyst Kelly Dougherty in a research note. "We expect more of the same solid performance at the highly profitable and high-ROIC (return on invested capital) Ground segment and continued improvement in Freight as evidence that FDX can fire on all cylinders in FY '15."

Just like last year's, the 2015 open-enrollment period for ObamaCare has been a success — if you ignore young adults and people who don't get subsidies.

The Congressional Budget Office expected 3 million people ineligible for subsidies to enroll in the exchanges this year, but fewer than 1.68 million signed up for coverage, and actual enrollment may drop once nonpayers are axed from the total.
Instead of the unsubsidized share of exchange members rising from 15% in 2014 to 25% this year, as CBO expected, the share paying full freight for ObamaCare slipped to 14%.
Just like last year, 28% of signups were age 18 to 34, far below their estimated 40% share of the potential exchange population.

If participation among young adults had matched their share of the population among the expected 12 million exchange members, then 4.8 million young adults would have enrolled — but just 3.25 million selected plans.

Those two categories, the young and unsubsidized, likely overlap to a significant extent. The Kaiser Family Foundation health subsidy calculator shows that a 30-year-old earning $33,000, about 285% of the poverty level, is ineligible for subsidies.

The huge shortfall among the young and unsubsidized may have obscured the fact that among everyone else — especially 55 and over — ObamaCare enrollment has gone pretty much as expected, if not better.
The sign-up total through Feb. 21 was 11.7 million, and perhaps one million of those won't pay based on last year's experience, leaving somewhere in the ballpark of 10.7 million paid enrollees.

Adults age 55 and up account for just 17% of the potential exchange pool, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. That proportion would have meant just over 2 million of the 12 million enrollment goal, but just over 3 million signed up, or 26% of the total.
Just like last year, 54% of exchange sign-ups were women.

The lack of improvement for ObamaCare in any of these metrics in the second year appears to be a somewhat negative sign for the future of the exchanges. Women, older adults and lower-income (i.e. subsidized) enrollees all represent somewhat costlier groups than those which are under-represented: men, young adults and the middle class.

There was an expectation built into the law that a higher-cost group would sign up first, but things would balance out over the first few years. The 2015 signup data suggest slow progress toward achieving a balance and that's probably not great news for 2016 premiums.

ObamaCare included two programs, reinsurance and risk corridors, to limit the financial risk faced by insurers in the first three years, encouraging them to price premiums low. Yet reinsurance will offer very modest support in 2016 — covering 50% of a patient's bills between $90,000 and $250,000, after reimbursing costs starting at $45,000 in 2015 — and insurers face great uncertainty about whether risk-corridor funds will be available to offset at least 50% of their losses.

With federal supports unwinding, insurers will begin to set premiums based on the expected cost of their plan members, and the demographics of the exchange population may be improving too slowly to avoid big rate hikes.

Even before the new HHS data, CBO said this week that it expects premium hikes will average 8.5% per year over the next three years, based on the phase-out of reinsurance and the push-back (by either customers, providers or regulators) against narrow networks and low payments to providers.

Concern about next year's rates may have been on the mind of the Obama administration when it put in place a special enrollment period through April for people who are hit with an individual mandate tax penalty for lacking coverage in 2014.

Whether next year's penalty, equal to the greater of $325 per person or 2% of taxable income, will get many more people to sign up over the next eight weeks remains to be seen. Many households eligible for subsidies can buy bronze coverage for less than the penalty. But for the unsubsidized, the individual mandate is likely to be less effective.Just like last year's, the 2015 open-enrollment period for ObamaCare has been a success — if you ignore young adults and people who don't get subsidies.The Congressional Budget Office expected 3 million people ineligible for subsidies to enroll in the exchanges this year, but fewer than 1.68 million signed up for coverage, and actual enrollment may drop once nonpayers are axed from the total.Instead of the unsubsidized share of exchange members rising from 15% in 2014 to 25% this year, as CBO expected, the share paying full freight for ObamaCare slipped to 14%.Just like last year, 28% of signups were age 18 to 34, far below their estimated 40% share of the potential exchange population.If participation among young adults had matched their share of the population among the expected 12 million exchange members, then 4.8 million young adults would have enrolled — but just 3.25 million selected plans.Those two categories, the young and unsubsidized, likely overlap to a significant extent. The average dividend mutual fund has outperformed the S&P 500 in the past 15 years.

Look what a $10,000 investment in the average dividend fund on Sept. 30, 1999, would have grown to by Dec. 10 this year: $26,484. The same investment in the S&P 500, a proxy for the broad stock market, would have trailed with $21,059, according to Morningstar Inc. data.
Few of the top performers yield as much as the S&P 500 and none have year-to-date gains that beat the index.

Vanguard Dividend Growth Fund has produced an average annual gain of 6.29% the past 15 years, compared with the S&P 500's 4.38%. The $23.4 billion fund has a 12-month yield of 1.77%. It's up about 10% this year vs. 12% for the S&P 500, which is a proxy for the broad stock market.

The fund is managed by Donald J. Kilbride of Wellington Management Co., which Vanguard hired as subadviser to the fund. Kilbride focuses on high-quality companies that have both the ability and the commitment to grow their dividends over time.

Recent holdings include United Parcel Service (UPS), which has a yield of 2.4%, a dividend growth rate of 9% and a stability factor of 1, with lower numbers denoting the most stability.The average dividend mutual fund has outperformed the S&P 500 in the past 15 years.Look what a $10,000 investment in the average dividend fund on Sept. 30, 1999, would have grown to by Dec. 10 this year: $26,484. The same investment in the S&P 500, a proxy for the broad stock market, would have trailed with $21,059, according to Morningstar Inc. data.Few of the top performers yield as much as the S&P 500 and none have year-to-date gains that beat the index.Vanguard Dividend Growth Fund has produced an average annual gain of 6.29% the past 15 years, compared with the S&P 500's 4.38%. Stocks opened battling near break-even points Friday, unsettled by mixed earnings reports and wavering oil prices.
The Nasdaq held out a 0.2% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.2%.
Trade was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 6% lower on the NYSE compared with volume at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today borrowed premarket strength from Europe's advancing stocks and from an upward blip in oil prices. But oil fell back into mild losses, and a spray of blue chip earnings reports helped put a dent in early trade.
Economic news was also lukewarm. A preliminary U.S. manufacturing index from researcher Markit showed no change in January, at 53.7. That disappointed expectations for an uptick to 54.

Existing-home sales data were mixed, rising to an annualized rate of 5.04 million for December, according to the National Association of Realtors. That beat November's 4.92 sales pace, but stopped just short of economist projections for 5.05 million.
The Conference Board reported its Leading Economic Indicators Index eased to 0.5%, down from 0.6% in November. Analyst had estimated a dip to 0.4%.
In stocks, McDonald's (MCD) and General Electric (GE) edged higher, Kimberly Clark (KMB) and Rockwell Collins (COL) fell after reporting quarterly results.
Starbucks (SBUX) was a big early winner, up 6% to new highs after a strong Q4 report. The strong volume gain also broke the stock out past buy points at 83.43 and 84.30.
The IBD 50 list opened mixed, half up, half down.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 2% to top the list. The move sent shares past a 134.60 buy point in a seven-week flat base.
Ambarella (AMBA) dropped 2%, the widest loss on the list. The stock remains extended, trading below a Jan. 13 high and its 10-week line of support.

United Parcel Service (UPS) collapsed 10%. The freight heavyweight offered preliminary fourth-quarter earnings guidance far below consensus views. The gap-down loss pulled shares away from a new high, sending the stock through its 10-week moving average in heavy trade.

Chip sector stocks were taking some hard hits, led by KLA-Tencor (KLAC), which fell 7%. The chip equipment maker reported stronger-than-expected fiscal second-quarter sales and earnings. But management guided Q3 revenue and earnings well below consensus. The loss drove shares back below the stock's 10-week moving average in heavy trade.Stocks opened battling near break-even points Friday, unsettled by mixed earnings reports and wavering oil prices.The Nasdaq held out a 0.2% gain. China-based stocks trading in the U.S. pulled back Tuesday after notching general gains on Monday and after a swarm of IPO approvals raised concerns over liquidity in Chinese markets.
But a number of U.S.-traded leaders still remained in healthy chart positions.
JD.com (JD) had a tough day, despite reporting an unexpected Q4 profit and better-than-forecast revenue growth.
Those results sent shares surging 6% in early trade to break out above a 28.59, cup-with-handle buy point.
The stock then pulled back to end the session down nearly 1%. More than 19 million American depositary shares traded hands during the session, its heaviest volume day since December.
The online retailer focusing on consumer electronics and home appliances ended Tuesday 4% below its buy point, but 46% above its May IPO price. It has been shaping its current base since August.
Tencent (TCEHY), a diversified online giant, pulled back a bit more than 1% in soft trade.

In addition to being a leader in online games, it owns WeChat, a microblogging service with a subscriber base reported at nearly 500 million. It owns minority stakes in WeBank, BitAuto (BITA) and other operations.
The stock briefly cleared a cup base in January. It then set up in a flat base with a 17.83 buy point.
The stock has repeatedly stalled at resistance just below 18, and the question is whether it will maintain its holding pattern until its March 18 earnings report.
UBS analyst Erica Poon Werkun expects a 22% revenue gain in Q4.
She also projects 63.1% gross margin, driving net profit ahead 46%.
Online apparel retailer Vipshop (VIPS) briefly cleared, then fell below a 23.06 handle buy point just ahead of its Q4 report.
It gapped past that buy point in massive volume Feb. 17 after clobbering Q4 expectations. It is now 7% past that buy point, consolidating just below its Feb. 25 high.
On the injured list, investment adviser Noah (NOAH) dropped 10% Tuesday in heavy volume.
That loss sent shares 6% below a 22.33 buy point in a double-bottom base.

Mobile game publisher Glu Mobile (GLUU) saw its shares skyrocket like a firework on Thursday after the company announced it is making a video game featuring pop singer Katy Perry.

The game will feature Perry's voice, likeness and personality and will launch in late 2015 for Apple (AAPL) iOS and Google (GOOGL) Android smartphones and tablets, Glu said in a press release late Wednesday. The announcement came three days after Perry earned positive reviews for her bubbly halftime performance at Super Bowl XLIX.

"We anticipate that Katy's significant global audience, including more than 170 million fans on social media, will make her a strong gaming partner for Glu," Glu CEO Niccolo de Masi said in a statement. Glu signed a five-year partnership with Perry.
Glu stock was up 30% in late afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 5.

Glu already has found success with a celebrity-themed game, "Kim Kardashian: Hollywood." That title, featuring the reality TV star, raked in $74.3 million in 2014 and accounted for 31% of Glu's revenue last year. The game has been downloaded more than 28 million times. In the fourth quarter, the Kardashian game raked in $29.3 million in sales, or 38% of the company's total revenue.

Like the Kardashian game, the Perry title is expected to be a free-to-play title. Under the freemium model, players download games for free, but are encouraged to make in-app purchases of extras to enhance the experience.

This isn't Perry's first video game. In 2012, she signed a multigame collaboration with Electronic Arts (EA). She was featured in expansion packs for EA's "The Sims 3," including "Katy Perry's Sweet Treats" and the "Katy Perry Collector's Edition" of the "Showtime" pack. "The Sims" is a life-simulation video game series.
Perry is a chart-topping performer known for such hit songs as "California Gurls," "Teenage Dream," "Firework," "Roar" and "Dark Horse."
Inspired by the success of "Kim Kardashian: Hollywood," mobile game studio Space Inch in December released "Lindsay Lohan's The Price of Fame." The game featured reality TV starlet Lohan.

Glu late Wednesday reported fourth-quarter results that beat expectations. The San Francisco company earned 11 cents a share, excluding items, on sales of $76 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Glu to earn 2 cents a share on sales of $64 million.

Glu's CEO told Bloomberg that a partnership with another celebrity might come later this year. The company also is looking at the sports segment for possible tie-ups, de Masi said.Mobile game publisher Glu Mobile (GLUU) saw its shares skyrocket like a firework on Thursday after the company announced it is making a video game featuring pop singer Katy Perry.The game will feature Perry's voice, likeness and personality and will launch in late 2015 for Apple (AAPL) iOS and Google (GOOGL) Android smartphones and tablets, Glu said in a press release late Wednesday. Shares of Arctic Cat (ACAT) sank on Wednesday after the snowmobile and all-terrain vehicle manufacturer slashed its full-year outlook, citing high ATV inventory and a difficult international environment, even though the company's third-quarter earnings per share topped expectations.The company now expects 2015 sales of $705 million-$715 million, down from an earlier forecast of $745 million-$755 million and far short of analyst expectations of $748 million. Arctic Cat forecast 2015 adjusted earnings per share of $1.24-$1.32, cut from the company's prior view of $1.55 to $1.65 and not at all close to analyst expectations for 1.97.Arctic Cat said it would take a $7 million charge this year to help reduce dealers' older inventory more quickly. The company also said international sales would fall this year due to "macroeconomic headwinds" and adverse foreign exchange in Canada, where Arctic Cat gets a third of its yearly sales."Fiscal 2015 is a challenging year of transition where we are resetting our strategic priorities to deliver improved long-term performance," said CEO Christopher Metz, who assumed the post last month to turn the underperforming company around after the departure of Claude Jordan. "At this time, we are lowering our fiscal 2015 full-year outlook for sales and earnings as we work through existing challenges. As we stated in the 2015 second quarter, one of our biggest challenges is rightsizing our core North America ATV dealer inventory levels. Bold actions are necessary to return to growth."Shares fell 2.5% to 28.97 in the stock market today after hitting a three-year low of 26 early. The stock has tumbled over the past year after a series of disappointing earnings reports.Arctic Cat's EPS for the third quarter, which ended Dec. 31, slid 23% from a year earlier to 68 cents. But that soundly beat analyst estimates for 48 cents.Revenue fell 14% to $193.74 million, missing views for $198 million. Snowmobile sales fell 30% from a year ago to $81.5 million. That decline was largely the result of the timing of snowmobile shipments to an original equipment manufacturing partner. Those shipments were moved to fiscal Q1 and Q2, Arctic Cat says.Sales of ATV and side-by-side vehicles, however, rose 7% to $78.2 million. Sales gains in the company's Wildcat off-road vehicle did much of the heavy lifting, as core ATV sales fell, the company said.Sales of parts, garments and accessories fell 4%, weighed by sales snow-related parts, which suffered due to less snow, the company says.The results come a day after Polaris (PII), Arctic Cat's much bigger rival, said in its Q4 report that snowmobile sales rose 2% to $138.1 million due to an earlier winter in North America. Polaris, which also manufactures off-road vehicles and motorcycles, reported estimate-topping Q4 results but guided 2015 cautiously. Off-road-vehicle sales jumped 19%.Polaris shares fell 1.4% Wednesday afternoon after rising 5.4% on Tuesday.Harley-Davidson (HOG), the best known of this trio of boy toys for grown-ups, was unchanged in early afternoon trading.

Women tend to use more medical care than men…
In gauging whether ObamaCare exchange policies make health care reasonably affordable, federal enrollment data have been little help.
They've offered no clarity on a key metric: the type of policies that households with modest incomes are buying.

But evidence from the one state that's breaking out such data suggests cause for concern: In Washington, one in four individuals in households earning less than 250% of the poverty level signed up for a bronze plan with a deductible of $5,000-$6,350 per person and $10,000-$12,700 per family.
Even after premiums, these households could face medical costs ranging from 17% to 40% of income before ObamaCare's nonpreventative-care benefits kick in.

By any standard, these enrollees hailed by many ObamaCare defenders as success stories are woefully underinsured. The Commonwealth Fund, which studies the health care system, generally considers a person who has to pay at least 10% of income on medical care (excluding premiums) to be underinsured. Households earning under 200% of the poverty level, whose budgets are already stretched, are deemed underinsured if medical costs take up even 5% of income.

The nature of ObamaCare's subsidies has set up what for many individuals and families may be a coverage decision with no good choices. They can stretch their budgets up to, if not beyond, the breaking point to buy generous coverage — or face financial disaster if they get a low-cost, high-deductible plan and wind up in the hospital.

As the Commonwealth Fund warns, modest-income households with insurance "who face high out-of-pocket costs for medical care relative to their incomes are nearly as likely as the uninsured population to go without care because of costs (or) forgo care when sick."

Beyond the premium subsidies that the law provides, households earning up to 250% of the poverty level qualify for cost-sharing assistance. It can greatly reduce the deductible that must be exhausted before benefits kick in and, after that, the co-payments required for medical services and prescription drugs.

But those cost-sharing subsidies are available only for those who buy silver-level coverage, a decision made by the law's crafters that might have held down ObamaCare's cost but looks questionable in light of the Washington state data.

Consider a single 40-year-old in King County who makes twice the poverty level ($22,980): That individual would have to pay $1,080, or 4.7% of income, in premiums for the cheapest silver plan with a $250 deductible. If $1,080 seems too pricey, the cheapest bronze plan would cost only $370, or 1.6% of income, but it carries a $6,000 deductible. The deductible applies not just to medical visits but to prescriptions as well.

While strained household budgets may have led some low-income enrollees to opt for a bronze plan, limited understanding of health insurance and the concept of deductibles and co-pays may explain why some selected low-cost bronze plans.
The Department of Health and Human Services has reported that of just over 8 million ObamaCare exchange sign-ups through mid-April, 1.6 million, or 20%, selected bronze plans.
The most useful data point provided by HHS: In the 36 states using the federal Healthcare.gov sign-up site, 688,000, or 15%, of those qualifying for subsidies have selected bronze plans.
Still, these data are of limited use in gauging affordability because they include households making up to 400% of the poverty level. They also include all sign-ups — not just those who pay.

The Washington state figures reflect only paid enrollment, but even these data have shortcomings. The state breaks subsidized enrollees into two groups: those earning up to 250% of the poverty level and those earning more.

It would be useful to know the age of the bronze-plan enrollees and how many earn only 200% of the poverty level. For example, a high-deductible plan may not be as much of a concern for a 32-year-old at 245% of the poverty level as a 52-year-old at 150% of poverty.
Advocates for low-income families in Minnesota have criticized ObamaCare's "bronze plan trap" which will get even worse next year, when ObamaCare deductibles rise as high as $6,600.

Families "with little to no discretionary income left after paying for essentials like food, housing, transportation and child care . . . are likely to fall into the 'bronze plan trap,' where they select the zero-premium bronze plan but must pay high deductibles and co-payments when they seek health care," said the Minnesota Budget Project, which analyzes budget and tax issues.
The Minnesota Budget Project warned that the likely result would be "poor health outcomes and more costly medical interventions later on."
Minnesota is the only state so far to implement what some have seen as an antidote to ObamaCare's bronze problem: a state-run public plan covering households earning up to 200% of the poverty level.

This option, known as the Basic Health Plan option, was included in the 2010 Affordable Care Act. But this option may have a downside. Because Minnesota's ObamaCare exchange sign-ups generally earn more than 200% of the poverty level, it is attracting an older population, with three adults age 55 and up for every two young adults.

It remains to be seen if Minnesota's exchange risk pool is healthier, which would offset upward pressure on premiums that may result from an older tilt.In gauging whether ObamaCare exchange policies make health care reasonably affordable, federal enrollment data have been little help.They've offered no clarity on a key metric: the type of policies that households with modest incomes are buying.But evidence from the one state that's breaking out such data suggests cause for concern: In Washington, one in four individuals in households earning less than 250% of the poverty level signed up for a bronze plan with a deductible of $5,000-$6,350 per person and $10,000-$12,700 per family.Even after premiums, these households could face medical costs ranging from 17% to 40% of income before ObamaCare's nonpreventative-care benefits kick in.By any standard, these enrollees hailed by many ObamaCare defenders as success stories are woefully underinsured. Households earning under 200% of the poverty level, whose budgets are already stretched, are deemed underinsured if medical costs take up even 5% of income.The nature of ObamaCare's subsidies has set up what for many individuals and families may be a coverage decision with no good choices. Because Minnesota's ObamaCare exchange sign-ups generally earn more than 200% of the poverty level, it is attracting an older population, with three adults age 55 and up for every two young adults.It remains to be seen if Minnesota's exchange risk pool is healthier, which would offset upward pressure on premiums that may result from an older tilt.

The average employer-provided family health insurance premiums have climbed $2,976 since 2009, according to an annual Kaiser Family Foundation survey released this week. They're up $3,671 compared with the year before President Obama took office. That's despite Obama's repeated promises that the health care reform law he championed would cut premiums by $2,500 in his first term.
And while annual premium increases have moderated over the past two years, that's due to trends in the insurance market largely unrelated to ObamaCare, and trends the law could actually reverse.

The Kaiser survey found that the average family premium this year is $16,351, up 4% over last year, and up 22% since 2009. After adjusting for inflation, premiums climbed an average 3.2% a year in Obama's first term, higher than the 2.7% average during President Bush's last four years in office.

During his first campaign for president, Obama repeatedly claimed that his health reform plan would, as he said at a Virginia rally in 2008 "lower premiums by up to $2,500 for a typical family per year."
Nevertheless, the White House has been touting recent signs of health cost moderation as evidence that ObamaCare is "already working to reduce costs."
Officials cite the fact that national spending on health care climbed just 3.9% in 2011, the same as the previous two years, and the slowest increase since the 1960s.
But the trends driving the slowdown in health spending have little to do with the Affordable Care Act.

The sluggish economy played a big role. "The failure of the economy to bounce back as quickly as it has after past recessions has prolonged this dampening effect on health spending," noted Joseph Antos, a health care expert at the American Enterprise Institute.
Also important has been a broader shift that has been underway for years toward higher-deductible plans. These plans provide consumers with a stronger incentive to economize on health spending.
The Kaiser survey found, for example, that 78% of workers now face at least some deductible, up from 59% in 2008. And nearly a third has a deductible of at least $2,000, up from 12% in 2008.

In addition, the private insurance market has seen an explosion in Health Savings Account-type plans — an idea long championed by conservative Republicans — which combine high deductibles with a tax-free savings account that consumers can roll over if they don't spend it all in one year.
Kaiser found that one in five workers are now enrolled in an HSA-type plan, up from 8% in 2008.
A separate survey by America's Health Insurance Plans finds that more than 15 million people are now enrolled in HSA plans, up 15% from last year andmore than double the number in 2008.
Drew Altman, the Kaiser foundation's president, on a conference call with reporters called it "part of a quiet revolution in health insurance from more comprehensive to less comprehensive."

But it's clearly a revolution that can help control health costs. A Rand Corporation study last year — titled "Skin in the Game" — found that families in HSA-type plans spent 21% less, on average, in the first year after they switched from a traditional plan. The study found that annual health costs would fall $57 billion if half of workers signed up with an HSA.

Unfortunately, ObamaCare will likely shift the market in the opposite direction, toward less out-of-pocket spending, greater reliance on insurance to cover small health coasts, and higher premiums. ObamaCare, for example, already requires that preventive care be provided at no direct cost to the patient. It also puts strict limits on deductibles and out-of-pocket spending.
Shipping giant UPS (UPS) recently cited the costs of these changes as a reason why it was dropping coverage for the spouses of 15,000 of its white-collar workers.

And a report from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services projects that next year "out-of-pocket spending is projected to decline 1.5% as third-party coverage will cover expenses previously paid by consumers out of pocket."The average employer-provided family health insurance premiums have climbed $2,976 since 2009, according to an annual Kaiser Family Foundation survey released this week. This Labor Day, Tom Camp will go to his neighbor's house in Livonia, Mich., for a cookout, then watch a little football. This day is made for guys like him.
For 51 years, he's clocked in at package delivery firm United Parcel Service (UPS) as a delivery driver.
In that time, he's never had a single accident. He leads the entire company for his safety record.
Retirement? Not for this guy.
"I'd be bored to death," Camp, 73, told IBD with a chuckle.

Quitting's not on the agenda for John Hinrichs, 75, either. He's been working at Farmers & Merchants Bank of Long Beach, Calif., for nearly 50 years, now as chief financial officer. "I'm looking forward to the next 50 years at Farmers & Merchants," he said.
Building a long and satisfying career takes more than luck.
Camp and Hinrichs offer these hints:
• Choose wisely. Get your career right by digging deep to find out what kind of work you naturally like to do.
"You've got to like your job, or when you got your 30 years in, you would leave," Camp said.
The mission of making sure that objects reach their destinations in perfect shape has always appealed to him.
• Look around. Early in his career, Hinrichs had to make a difficult decision.
He was in the Marines and enjoyed its challenges. Since he was a teen he'd helped run his family dairy farm in Minnesota, and that was worthwhile too.
But he preferred the idea of going to college, then going into business.
Farmers & Merchants hired him to be a teller in 1964. He worked his way up.
• Stay true. Bad years, horrendous weather, technical glitches and busy seasons are all part of work.
To build your endurance, try not to let circumstances or snafus determine your attitude.
"On New Year's Eve, if we had to close the books and it went on until 2 or 3 in the morning, that was OK, that was expected," Hinrichs said.
• Stretch. One very snowy night, Camp's UPS truck got stuck. He didn't want to leave his packages behind, so he stayed with the rig.
A couple of hours later, a homeowner on his route invited him in for dinner.
Near midnight, a tow truck finally showed up. Camp's bosses were grateful that he looked out for the merchandise.
Faced with a similar situation, one of his colleagues locked up the truck and went home. "I don't think he's with the company anymore," Camp said.
• Connect. Never think of your customers as nameless money machines.
Though his routes have changed several times over the years, Camp makes it a point to get to know people getting parcels.
"I've got some people on my route who are older. They could be in their 80s," he said. "Instead of laying the package on the porch or between the door, I wait for them and put it inside."
• Get fit. Staying healthy and strong will help you do your job well beyond retirement age.
Hinrichs always stops by the gym before going to work.
"I get kidded every now and then. 'Do you ever miss a day?' No, I never miss a day," he said.
• Sharpen your mind. If your business is profitable, you'll always be using your noggin to learn how to do things better and use new technology.
That's been rocket fuel for keeping Hinrichs happy at work.

"Stay focused," he said. "Make learning a lifetime experience. Don't be clock punchers."This Labor Day, Tom Camp will go to his neighbor's house in Livonia, Mich., for a cookout, then watch a little football. Stocks rallied to new session highs near Thursday's halftime after bouncing back from earlier turbulence. The market has seen ups and downs amid news of the European Central Bank's bond buying, earnings and economic data.

The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 climbed 1% and 0.8%, respectively. Both regained their 50-day lines. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%. Volume was tracking higher across the board in the stock market today
In stocks, Southwest Airlines (LUV) jumped 7% to a record higher after reporting Q4 results that topped expectations.

Fellow airliner United Continental (UAL) ramped up 5% to a new high despite posting Q4 earnings below views. But it gave upbeat guidance for its Q1 profit margin. The stock is extended from a rebound off its 10-week line.

S&P Capital IQ's Jim Corridore kept a buy opinion on Southwest and a strong buy on United Continental. "We see valuations across the entire U.S. airline group likely to expand on positive sentiment, while earnings are likely to benefit from lower oil prices," he wrote in a research note.
Other airline stocks also cruised higher. JetBlue (JBLU) and Delta Air Lines (DAL) rallied 6% and 3%, respectively.

On the downside, F5 Networks (FFIV) was off its session low, but still down 12% on late Wednesday's disappointing quarterly sales and outlook. The stock gapped below its 200-day line and was down nearly 14% at Thursday's low.Stocks rallied to new session highs near Thursday's halftime after bouncing back from earlier turbulence.
